loans.name: Sahriati

texts.id:
Sahriati has for a long time now occupied herself with her food stall business. While it is not a large enterprise, it is the business that has really helped support the family. Her husband does not have a stable job and therefore no stable income, moreover, he very frequently helps Sahriati in running the stall. Sahriati and her husband are the only two members of their household since their children have married and moved out.

The DINARI Foundation's reach has expanded into her region, and Sahriati has gained their trust in order to obtain a loan from them. The funds are to increase working capital, namely to shop for all the various needs of the food stall. The necessities for the stall are purchased daily at the market, whereas the light snacks are purchased twice a week. The net proceeds each day can reach Rp. 100,000 (~ US$13) if there is a good crowd of customers and especially when fish are plentiful by the docks. Thankfully the stall is located near the docks, which enable them to source fish. From the stall's income Sahriati is able to lighten the load on her husband to provide for their family.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Aarati, Kiva volunteer.

Sahriati sudah cukup lama menekuni usaha warung.Walaupun masih tergolong kecil, namun itulah yang menjadi usaha yang sangat membantu pendapatan keluarga. Suaminya tidak mempunyai pekerjaan tetap sehingga tidak mempunyai penghasilan tetap, bahkan suami sering kali membantu Sahriati dalam menjalan usaha warungnya. Saat ini Sahriati hanya tinggal dengan suami saja sebab anaknya sudah semua menikah. Pelayanan Yayasan DINARI sampai di daerah tersebut dan akhirnya Sahriati mendapat kepercayaan dan memperoleh dana pinjaman. Dengan dana pinjaman tersebut dipakai untuk menambah modal usahanya yaitu untuk berbelanja segala keperluan usaha warung makannya. Untuk berbelanja kebutuhan warungnya dilakukan setiap hari dipasar, berbelanja makan ringan biasanya dilakukan dalam satu minggu dua kali. Keuntungan bersih dalam sehari mencapai Rp.100.000.- jika situasi sedang ramai pelanggan, terutama pada musim banyak ikan di dermaga. Kebetulan lokasi warungnya berada didekat dermaga ikan. Dari keuntungan inilah Sahriati dapat meringankan beban suaminya untuk menambah pendapatan keluarganya.

loans.use: Increase the business’s working capital in order to upgrade the level of service and the food selection in the stall

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Girah

texts.id:
Although situated in a coastal area, Girah does lose heart about her work. Girah has taken advantage of the activity near the docks by setting up a food stall. The idea and hope was that the ship crew would shop and have their meals at her stall. Her business has since developed regular clientèle who stop by for her simple and tasty fare.

Through her friend Girah received information and ultimately a loan from the DINARI foundation. The borrowed funds were used to open her food stall business. To sustain the business, Girah has to work around the clock, because the stall is located sea-side and there is a continuous flow of fishermen who anchor there to rest. Her husband devotes himself to keeping Girah company in the stall because their children are married and have moved out. They pour their energy into the business; even cooking and resting is done in the stall itself. With this same perseverance and effort ,Girah will improve the stall. She will develop it into a respectable place that is suitable for working out of and of which she can be proud.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Aarati, Kiva volunteer.

Walaupun letak daerah tempat tinggalnya yang dipesisir pantai, Girah tidak patah semangat dalam berusahanya.Girah memanfaatkan keramaian dermaga dengan membuka warung makanan. Dengan harapan para awak kapal dapat berbelanja dan makan pagi siang dan sore hari ditempatnya. Pelanggan pun sudah mulai terbiasanya dengan keberadaan warung makannya yang sangat sederhana. Melalui temannya Girah mendapat informasi dan akhirnya mendapat dan pinjaman dari yayasan DINARI. Dana pinjaman tersebut dipakai untuk mengembangkan usaha Warung makannya. Untuk menjalan usaha ini, Girah harus berjualan selama 24 jam nonstop,sebab warung terletak di daerah dermaga yang setiap saat ada nelayan yang berlabuh untuk beristirahat. Dengan setia Asbullah, suaminya, tetap menemani Girah di warungnya siang dan malam karena anak-anaknya sudah semua menikah. Semua kegiatan untuk menjalan usaha, baik memasak dan istirahat, dapat dilakukan diwarungnya. Dengan keuletan inilah Girah dapat memperbaiki warung sehingga layak untuk ditempati.

loans.use: Needs working capital to better equip the stall

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for DINARI Foundation - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Eko

texts.id:
Eko S. is a 32 year-old currently working as a distributor of children's toys. He sells children's toys to a retail agent who in turn sells them directly to customers. Toys come in many varieties; some for sale are made of plastic and paper. At this time he is proposing to borrow so that he can expand his business. He hopes that the income earned can boost his livelihood so that he can put aside savings for his child's education. Eko S. has one child with his wife Sri Romelah. They live on Jl. Pidada Denpasar, where they rent a house.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Aarati, Kiva Volunteer.

Eko S. (32) tahun, saat ini bekerja sebagai distributor mainan anak-anak. Dia menyalurkan mainan anak-anak kepada penjual eceran, yang nantinya akan langsung menjual ke konsumen. Adapun mainan yang dijual terbuat dari plastik dan kertas. Saat ini dia mengajukan pinjaman untuk dijadikan tambahan modal usaha. Diharapkan keuntungan yang didapat sekarang bisa meningkat dan bisa disisihkan untuk tabungan untuk pendidikan anaknya. Saat ini, Eko S. memiliki satu orang anak dari istrinya Sri Romelah. Mereka tinggal di Jl.Pidada Denpasar dengan mengontrak sebuah rumah.

loans.use: To increase working capital for his business

loans.name: Shamim's Group

texts.en:
Shamim baji is the widow of M. and lives in the city of Borewala, Pakistan. She has been living in this city for the last 30 years. Shamim baji is the mother of two sons, and both drive a transport truck. Shamim baji has a clothing business, and she is applying for a loan to buy more garments to expand her business.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members: Kanizan baji and Irshad baji each want a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (local three-wheeled motor vehicle); and Rashida baji wants a loan to buy garments for her clothing business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Shahnaz's Group

texts.en:
Shahnaz baji is the wife of M. S. and has lived in the city of Borewala, Pakistan for the past 3 years, where she owns a two room brick house. She is the mother of four children: one son and three daughters. Her children are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Her husband is a mason by profession. Shahnaz baji is a housewife and prefers to take care of her children. She is applying for a loan to buy masonry tools (beams, hammer) for her husband.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members: Shahida baji wants a loan to buy a juicer machine; Naziran baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (local three-wheeled motor vehicle); and Shakooran baji wants a loan to buy cloth to resell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Nagina's Group

texts.en:
Nagina baji is the wife of M. Y. and lives in the city of Borewala, Pakistan. She owns a two room brick house where she has lived for the past 3 years. She is the mother of six children: four sons and two daughters. Her two elder sons work in a marble factory. The next eldest to them has a butcher business. Her youngest son is in 7th standard. Her two daughters are in 8th standard (level). Her husband has a Punjabi food (samosas) business and has been in this profession for the last 3 years. Nagina baji successfully completed her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan for her husband so that he can buy more goods for making the food.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members: Shahnaz baji and Ruqaiya baji each want a loan to buy thread for their carpet weaving businesses; Zubaida baji wants a loan to produce ceiling material; and Haleema baji wants a loan to buy more plants for her plants business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Asia's Group

texts.en:
Asia baji is a wife of M. and lives in a city named Borewala, Pakistan. She has a two room brick house where she has lived for the last year. She is the mother of two sons. Her husband has a milk shop and has been in this profession for the last 2 years. She successfully completed her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more milk for her husband’s milk shop.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members: Saleema baji wants a loan to buy more meat for her meat shop; Noshaba baji wants a loan to buy more cloth for her cloth business; Rashidan baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine and thread for her sewing shop; and Siddiqan baji wants a loan to expand her grocery shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Nusrat's Group

texts.en:
Nusrat baji is the wife of S. H. and has lived in the city of Burewala, Pakistan for the past 10 years. She owns a two room brick house, and is the mother of two sons. Her elder son is in kindergarten. Her husband is a driver and has been in this profession for the last 10 years. He drives a rented auto-rickshaw (local three-wheel vehicle). Nusrat baji successfully completed her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw for her husband.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Salma baji wants a loan to buy thread for her carpet weaving business. Zainab baji wants a loan to buy materials to make cosmetics.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en:
Naseem baji is the wife of G. M. and has lived in the city of Borewala, Pakistan for the last 25 years. She is the mother of four children: three sons and one daughter. Her elder son is a daily wage laborer, and the other three children are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Her husband is a vegetable seller and has been in this profession for the last 10 years. She successfully completed her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more vegetables for her husband’s business.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Shamim baji wants a loan to buy cosmetics to resell. Sakina baji wants a loan to buy thread for her carpet weaving business. Salma baji wants a loan to buy more milk for her milk business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Irshad's Group

texts.en:
Irshad baji is the wife of M. H. Jaffery and has lived in the city of Borewala, Pakistan for the past 28 years. She owns a two room brick house. Irshad baji and her family are very well educated. She and her elder daughter finished their Masters degrees. Irshad baji is the mother of seven children: four sons and three daughters. Her second eldest daughter is also a teacher and completed her Bachelors degree. Her eldest daughter will start a job as a teacher right after finishing her Masters degree. Her youngest daughter is in 11th standard (grade). Her eldest son and the next eldest completed 12th standard (grade) and started making bicycle springs. Her two younger sons completed their Bachelors degrees and are army officers. Her husband is a land owner and completed his Bachelors degree. She successfully completed her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy more materials for her sons’ bicycle spring business.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Rubina baji wants a loan to buy animals food to resell. Ramzan baji wants a loan to buy a floor waxing machine. Shamim baji wants a loan to buy more inventory for her grocery shop. Muniran baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (local three-wheel vehicle).

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Irshad's Group

texts.en:
Irshad baji is the wife of M. A. and has lived in the city of Borewala, Pakistan for the past 10 years. She is the mother of three daughters, and they are all in kindergarten. Her husband is a mason and has been in this profession for the last 5 years. She successfully completed her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy masonry tools (beams, rope) for her husband.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members: Shahnaz baji wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (local three-wheeled motor vehicle); Iqbal baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine; and Nazia baji wants a loan to buy thread for her carpet weaving business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Mwaache

texts.en:
Mwaache is 31 years old. She is married and has 1 child, age 3. Mwaache began her own business in 2004, and sells a variety of snack and food products. She works every day and earns a monthly profit of around $35.

In the past, Mwaache has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. Mwaache now hopes for a loan to purchase more items and continue to expand her customer base.

loans.use: To increase her inventory.

loans.name: Wanu

texts.en:
Wanu is 32 years old. She is married, and has 3 children, ages 7, 12, and 13. Wanu began her own business in 2004, and sells a variety of products, including charcoal and firewood. She works everyday from 6am to 8pm, and earns a monthly profit of around $44.

In the past, Wanu has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. Wanu now hopes for a loan to purchase more items and continue to expand her customer base.

loans.use: To increase her inventory.

loans.name: Salma

texts.en:
Salma is 37 years old. She is married, and has 7 children between the ages of 5 and 20. Selma began her own business in 2003, and sells a variety of products, including charcoal, fuel, and cassava. She works everyday from 6am to 6pm, and earns a monthly profit of around $43.

In the past, Salma has taken out 2 successful loans from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. Salma now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal, firewood and cassava and expand her customer base.

loans.use: To buy more items to increase her business.

loans.name: Msimu

texts.en:
Msimu is 40 years old. She is married, and has 7 children between the ages of 2 and 25. In 2004, Msimu began selling rice, beans, bananas, and coconuts. She works everyday from 7 AM to 8 PM, and earns a monthly profit of around $250 from her sales.

In the past, Msimu has completed one successful loan from BRAC Tanzania to expand her business. She would now like another loan in order to increase the number of items she sells in her business.

loans.use: To increase her stock.

loans.name: Hekima Group

texts.en: Anna S. is hoping to expand the clothing shop that she started in Arusha in 2007.  She is married with three children, ages 11, 7, and 6.  She works every day from 9:00am to 4:00pm and can make a monthly profit of approximately $18.  With this loan, she hopes to increase her profit and grow her business.  She has taken out one previous loan through BRAC Tanzania which she repaid on time.

loans.use: To grow her small clothing shop.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is 47 years old. She is married, and has 5 children between the ages of 20 and 33. Mariam began her own business in 2001, and sells a variety of bed-sheets, shoes, and hand bags. She works everyday from 11am to 4pm, and can earn a profit of around $40 from her sales per month.

Mariam has already successfully completed 2 loans from BRAC Tanzania. She would like to request another loan in order to purchase more items and expand her inventory and stock. In addition, she will also share this loan with her subgroup members, who all have their own businesses dealing with various food sales.

loans.use: To buy more shoes, bedsheet and handbag to increase her stock.

loans.name: Fatma's Shukrani Group

texts.en:
Fatma is married, and has 2 children, ages 10 and 14. She became a fish seller in 2000. Everyday, she works from 10am to 6pm at her business, and earns a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

Fatma is now requesting a loan to purchase more fish for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who all have businesses dealing with various food sales.

loans.use: To buy more fish for her business.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace has owned a small clothing business in Arusha since 2002.  She is 23 years old, married, and has two children ages 5 and one and a half.  She works daily from 9:00am to 6:00pm for a monthly profit of approximately $130.  She is requesting this loan in order to buy more clothing at bulk rates to sell in her shop.

loans.use: To buy more clothing for sale in her business.

loans.name: Mariam's Shukuri Group

texts.en:
Mariam is 48 years old, married, and has 4 children between the ages of 6 and 23. She began her own business in 2006, selling various items such as soaps, firewood, and charcoal. Mariam works everyday from 7 AM to 6 PM, and she earns on average a monthly profit of $40 from her sales.

Mariam is now requesting a loan to purchase more charcoal, firewood, and soap for her business. She will also share this loan with her subgroup members, who all have their own respective businesses in various trades, such as food sales and tailoring.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Anorboi

texts.en:
Anorboi A. first applied  to  MicroInvest in 2008 but he could recommend himself as a serious and reliable client. Mr. A. was born in 1960 in the B.Gafurov region of Tajikistan and ever since he was a young man, he has been engaged in the livestock business. First he helped his father to take care of their livestock. Now he has his own livestock business and dreams of owning an outlet where he can sell meat and meat products. 

Mr. A. also works in the pumping station but the main business in his life is his livestock. Mr. A. is applying to KIVA to request a business development loan of 2100 STJ for 6 months to purchase a new pedigreed bull.

loans.use: purchasing a new pedigreed bull

loans.name: Riziki's Shukrani Group

texts.en:
Riziki is 37 years old, married, and has 3 children ages 4, 8, and 15. Riziki opened her own tailoring business in 2006, and works everyday from 7 AM to 10 PM. On average, she can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from sales.

Riziki is now requesting a loan in order to expand the number of items she can sell. She will also share this loan with her subgroup members, who all have businesses selling various foods such as tea, cashews, and rice.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Sobirjon

texts.en:
Sobirjon A.  has been engaged in the livestock business ever since he was a young man. The love of animals brings him to this kind of business. He was born in 1967 and lives in the Ismoil region of Tajikistan. It is the family business so his wife and children help him to take care of the animals and make the milk products that they sell in the local bazaar. 

Besides the dairy business, Mr. Sobirjon  A. sells fruit that he grows himself. He is a hard-working man. Mr. Sobirjon A.  is applying to KIVA for help in the form of a business support loan in the amount of 2800 STJ for 6 months to build a new shed for his cows.

loans.use: building a new cowshed

loans.name: Rehema

texts.en:
Rehema has owned her own livestock business in Arusha for 8 years. She is married with four children, ages 8, 15, 17, and 20. She works daily from 6:00am to 7:00pm and generates a monthly profit of approximately $30.

Rehema has taken out two previous loans through BRAC Tanzania to expand her livestock business. She paid back both successfully and on time. She would like to use this loan to create a new business in Arusha.

loans.use: To open another livestock business.

loans.name: Najminisso

texts.en:
Najminisso A.  lives in Kairakkum in Tajikistan. She is a single mother but she is full of enthusiasm and readiness to work hard to ensure her children a good and happy future. She works in a dining hall and she is a qualified cook. She has specialized education and knows how to make a lot of national dishes and other dishes. She is very polite and many people come her dining hall to eat.

Mrs. A.  is applying to KIVA for help in the form of a business development loan of 2800 STJ for 5 months for purchasing new equipment  and modernizing her workplace.

loans.use: purchasing new equipment, etc.

loans.name: Bugani's Hakinalawa Group

texts.en:
Bugani is 47 years old, married, and has 3 children ages 9, 10, and 13. In addition, Bugani cares for her mother, who is 90 years old. In 1999, Bugani opened her own business selling cakes and sweets (referred to locally as “bites”). Everyday, she works from 9 AM to 9 PM, and earns a monthly profit of around $40.

Bugani would like to request a loan to purchase more items for her business. In addition, she will also share her loan with her subgroup members, who all have businesses that sell clothes, shoes, salon products, oils, fish, and other various foods.

loans.use: To buy more items to increase her stock.

loans.name: Helga

texts.en:
Helga has owned her own food shop in Arusha for two years. She is 35 years old, married, and has two children ages 5 and 7. She works every day from 7:00am to 7:30pm and is able to generate a monthly profit of $50.

Helga has taken out one previous loan through BRAC Tanzania. She paid it back successfully and on time. She would like to take out this loan so that she may buy more goods for sale in her shop, like sugar and salt.

loans.use: To buy sugar and salt to expand her business.

loans.name: Saidaniso

texts.en:
Saidaniso J.  is 31 years old. She is married and has 4 children. She has not had higher or special education so after her marriage she had to stay at home and help her mother-in-law. But she loves her family and found herself in the livestock business. She loves animals and takes care of livestock. Besides she is engaged in making and selling milk products. 

Mrs. Saidaniso J.  is applying to KIVA for a business support loan in the amount of 2100 STJ for 6 months to purchase another milch-cow.

loans.use: purchasing another milch-cow

loans.name: Hosana Group

texts.en:
Silvia has owned her own fish-selling business in Arusha for six years. She is single and has no children. She works daily from 8:00am to 10:00pm and generates a monthly profit of approximately $350. She is requesting a loan in order to buy fish for her business and increase her profit.

Silvia will share this loan with her group member, Anna C., who owns her own shop in which she sells groceries.

loans.use: To buy more fish to expand her business.

loans.name: Muyassar

texts.en:
Muyassar K.  lives in Khujand. She is 47 years old. Mrs. K. is a seamstress by profession. She is a very knowledgeable worker and has repeat customers since she has a good reputation as a competent seamstress. Mrs. K. has been working in this sphere for the last 27 years. She uses both traditional and European motifs in her work and is engaged in making traditional and European wear. 

Mrs. K. is applying to KIVA for help in the form of a business development loan of 1250 STJ for 6 months to purchase modern equipment.

loans.use: purchasing modern equipment

loans.name: Mpenami's Wastara Group

texts.en:
Mpenami is 39 years old, married, and has 5 children between the ages of 4 and 22. She entered the clothing industry in 2007, and opened her own small store. Everyday, she works from 10:30 AM to 3:30 PM. On average, Mpenami can earn a monthly profit of $125 from her sales.

Mpenami now hopes for a loan that would enable her to purchase more clothing and more items for her business. She will also share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses selling fish, charcoal, coconuts, cakes, and firewood.

loans.use: To increases her inventory

loans.name: Neema

texts.en: Neema has owned a clothing business in Arusha for one year.  She is 24 years old, married, and has one 4-year-old child.  She works daily from 9:00am to 4:00pm and is able to generate a monthly profit of approximately $18.  She is hoping to take out a loan in order to buy more clothing at bulk rates to sell in her shop.

loans.use: To buy more clothing to sell at her business.

loans.name: Thi Xuan's Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. V. Thi Xuan (ID Number 13010001), 55 years old, has borrowed through the SEDA Fund one time. This time, she would like to borrow 4,704,000VND to buy and sell general goods. Her daily income is 100.000VND (about 6USD). Her group also consists of:
  • Mrs. N. Thi Ba (ID Number 13010002), borrows 4,256,000VND to buy and sell general goods
  • Mrs. D. Thi Nam (ID Number 13010003), borrows 4,704,000VND to buy and sell general goods
  • Mrs. D. Thi Thuy (ID Number 13010004), borrows 4,256,000VND to sell drinks
  • Mrs. N. Thi Huong (ID Number 13010005), borrows 4,704,000VND to invest in her eatery
  • The total amount requested is 1,375.00USD

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Pham Yen Thanh, Kiva Volunteer.

    chị Vũ thị Xuân năm nay 55 tuổi , MS 13010001 cô đã tham gia được một chu kỳ .Đợt này cô vay số tiền là 4.704000VND,để đi chợ và mỗi ngày cô thu nhập được hơn 100.000VND.Tronng nhóm của cô gồm có các thành viên:

  • Nguyễn thị Ba MS 13010002 vay mức 4.256000 VND để đi chợ
  • Đinh thị Năm MS 13010003 vay mức 4.704000 VND để kinh doanh
  • Đinh thị Thuỷ MS 13010004 vay mức 4.256000 VND để bán hàng giải khát
  • chị Nguyễn thị Hương MS 13010005 vay mức 4.704000 VND bán hàng cơm

loans.use: Selling general goods

loans.name: Snježana

texts.en: Snježana is a woman living in the town of Doboj.  She is married with one young child, and she and her husband run a small convenience store. She is requesting her first loan with Žene za Žene in the amount of 600 KM to invest in her store, specifically to stock up on inventory.  Snježana wants to increase the variety of products she sells at her shop, and believes that this investment will be the best way to increase her income and in turn improve her family’s standard of living.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her store

loans.name: Effah

texts.en:
M. Effah is a baker of bread. She is married, but her husband's income as a farmer is not sufficient for M. and her 6 children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Women Group

texts.en:
Lucy has owned a tailoring business in Arusha for eight years. She is 34 years old, married, and has two children ages 3 and 8. She works every day from 7:00am to 9:00pm and generates a monthly profit of approximately $250.

Lucy has taken out two previous loans through BRAC Tanzania. She paid back both successfully and on time. She is hoping to use this loan to buy a sewing machine and other items to help her run her business. She will be sharing this loan with her three other group members who also own retail shops. Their shops sell beer, vegetables, and clothing, respectively.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine and other items for her business.

loans.name: Johari's Wastara Group

texts.en:
Johari is 27 years old. She is a married woman with three children aged 8, 6 and 2. She also takes care of one other child, aged 5. She has been a tailor and a used clothes saleswoman since 2006. Every day, she works from 6.30am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

Johari now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes and tailoriong items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses dealing with juice sales, charcoal sales, and clothes (bedsheet) sales.

loans.use: To buy more clothes and tailoring items for her business.

loans.name: Biljana

texts.en:
Biljana is a young woman from the town of Doboj. She is married with one child, and her husband currently works full time. Biljana runs a small shop where she sells a variety of goods, including drinks, snacks, and some personal hygiene products.

She is requesting this first loan in the amount of 600 KM to use to purchase more inventory for her store. Her husband’s salary is not enough to support the whole family, and Biljana is having trouble meeting all of her overhead costs at the moment. She hopes that by taking this loan she can have more available to sell up front and that this will lead to an increase in her income.

loans.use: To buy more inventory to support her store

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel E. sells a variety of things, including drinks. He is married, but his wife's income as a petty trader is not sufficient for Emmanuel and his 5 children. Demand for his goods is high, and he is looking to expand his business to increase his profits.

He is asking for additional capital to expand his business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand his business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Zuhura's Wastara Group

texts.en:
Zuhura is a married woman with six children between 4 and 24. She began selling bites in 2008. Every day, she works from 8am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Zuhura now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses selling charcoal, bites, clothes, and porridge.

loans.use: To increase her inventory

loans.name: Elizabeth's Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth has owned a business selling clothing and providing salon services in Arusha since 1990. She is 38 years old, divorced, and has three children ages 16, 21, and 25. She works every day from 9:00am to 6:00pm and is able to make a monthly profit of approximately $300.

Elizabeth has taken out two previous loans through BRAC Tanzania. She paid both back successfully and on time. She hopes to use this current loan to buy more clothing at the bulk rate to then sell for a profit at her shop. She would also like to open another business.

loans.use: To buy more clothing to sell in her business.

loans.name: Ith

texts.en:
Mr. Ith K. is married with five children and lives with his wife at Bathambong province, Cambodia. He works as a motor-taxi driver transporting passengers from place to place, making around $3 per day of income. His client base is at a market near his town. Meanwhile, his wife is employed by the local gas station and she can make about $3 each day. One of her children works at a restaurant and the other four are students. The income he and his wife make is used to cover all of their family's expenses, including her children's tuition.

Mr. Ith K. is now seeking a loan to purchase a new motor-bike to replace his old one which is frequently broken and wastes his family a lot of money. A new motor-bike could not only reduce his expense but also could make his clients much more comfortable.

loans.use: To buy a new motor-bike to replace his old one

loans.name: Abdulla Najeeb

texts.en:
Abdulla Najeeb is 22 years old and single. He has a dress shop that he has been involved in for more than 5 years. Najeed was in Iran for a long time where he worked in a shop. When he came back he started working in Kabul and his business is going well.

He would like to expand his business so he wants to take out an individual loan to complete his stock and enlarge his shop. He is sure that he can further his business with this loan and make a better future for himself .

He is happy with this loan and he hopes that he is going to a great business dealer in the future. He would like to thank Kiva lenders who help poor people around the world, especially In Afghanistan.

loans.use: To complete his stock and enlarge his shop

loans.name: Amina

texts.en:
Amina is 25 years old. She is a married woman with 2 children, aged 8 and 2. She owns and runs a small decoration shop, which she started in 2006. Every day, she works at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Amina now hopes for a loan to buy more decorations items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more decoration items for her shop.

loans.name: Gladness' Group

texts.en:
Gladness has owned and run a salon in Arusha for ten years. She is 28 years old, married, and has one 10-year-old child. She works daily from 8:00am to 7:00pm and generates a monthly profit of approximately $300.

Gladness has taken out two previous loans through BRAC Tanzania. She paid both back successfully and on time. She is hoping to use this current loan to buy more materials to expand her business. She will be sharing this loan with her group members who also own small businesses in Arusha.

loans.use: To buy more materials to improve her salon.

loans.name: Ly

texts.en:
Mr. Ly S., 27, is a father of one little child and works as a motor-taxi driver, making around $3 each day. His client base is mostly at a market near his town. His wife works as a gardener and can make only $1 each day.

Mr. Ly S. and his wife are concerned about the small amount of income they make compared to recent inflation. He mentioned that previously the income of $4 per day was enough to cover his family’s expenses such as utilities, food and gasoline, but today everything is very expensive, especially rice and gas, so their income is barely enough and it is pretty hard for them.

In order to overcome their obstacles, Mr. Ly S. is asking for a loan amount of $1000 to build a stand for his wife to sell meatballs and food products to the people in her area. With any leftover money, S. will replace his old motor-bike which is often broken and costs him a lot of money.

loans.use: To open a stand for his wife to sell meatballs and food products.

loans.name: Eliza's Group

texts.en:
Eliza has owned a salon and sold decorative crafts in Arusha since 2003. She is 40 years old, single, and has no children. She works daily from 8:00am to 9:00pm and generates a monthly profit of approximately $200.

Eliza has taken out two previous loans from BRAC Tanzania. She paid them both back successfully and on time. She hopes to use this current loan to buy more items for her decorative crafts business and to open a new business. She will share this loan with her two group members, Joyce and Lilian, who own clothing and food shops, respectively.

loans.use: To open a new business.

loans.name: Bahati's Shukrani Group

texts.en:
Bahati is 29 years old. She is a married woman with five children between 1 and 13. She also takes care of two other children, aged 12 and 18 years old. She is a livestock owner and sells charcoal and firewood, a business she started in 2002. Every day, she works from 7am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Bahati now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal and firewood for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses dealing with firewood, charcoal, oil, soup, juice, and livestock.

loans.use: To increase her inventory.

loans.name: Lilian's Group

texts.en:
Lilian has owned a shop in Arusha since 2005. She is 47 years old, married, and has four children, ages 18, 24, 27, and 37. She also cares for one 23-year-old dependent. She works at her shop daily from 8:00am to 8:00pm and generates a profit of approximately $200 each month.

Lilian has taken out two previous loans from BRAC Tanzania. She paid them both back successfully and on time. With this loan, she hopes to buy more materials to help her expand her business. She will be sharing this loan with her two group members, Frida and Grace. Frida owns a salon in Arusha, and Grace owns a butcher shop.

loans.use: To buy more items to increase her inventory

loans.name: Sichana's Hakinalawama Group

texts.en:
Sichana is 27 years old. She is a married woman with two children, aged 9 and 4. She becA. a poultry owner and soap seller in 2003. Every day, she works from 8am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

Sichana now hopes for a loan to buy more poultry and poultry feed for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses dealing with charcoal and firewood sales, fish sales, oil sales and tailoring.

loans.use: To more poultry and poultry food for her business.

loans.name: Mwatima

texts.en:
Mwatima is 43 years old. She is a married woman with two children, aged 20 and 19. She owns and runs a small general store, which she started in 1999. Every day, she works from 7:30am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Mwatima now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok V., 39, is as widow and has started business selling various kinds of grocery products since 2000 to the people in her community and typically makes around $4 per day in revenue. She has two children aged 15 and 10 who are enrolled in a primary school. Each month she spends around $30 on food, $10 on utilities and $50 for her children’s education.

A diligent mother, Mrs. Sok V. has to work very hard and to make sure that she can afford her family’s expenses. In the past she was a businesswoman who worked near the Thai border but because her son got seriously ill she decided to give up her business and came back home to look after her son and other kids. When she was back home she opened a grocery store.

Now she is asking for a loan to purchase more grocery products to expand her inventory. Her customers' demands are growing so she has to increase her products to meet their needs.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products to expand her inventory

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina has cooked and sold soup in Arusha since 1998. She is married with seven children, ages 26, 25, 21, 17, 11, and twin 12-year-olds. She works every day from 6:00am to 7:00pm and generates a profit of approximately $50 each month.

Regina has taken out two previous loans through BRAC Tanzania. She paid back both of the loans successfully and on time. She hopes to take out this loan in order to widen her business.

loans.use: To buy more materials to expand her business.

loans.name: Niceligaki's Group

texts.en:
Niceligaki has owned a business cooking and selling food in Arusha since 2001. She is divorced with two children, ages 8 and 11. She works from 6:00am to 2:00pm daily and generates a monthly profit of approximately $90.

Niceligaki has previously taken out two loans from BRAC Tanzania. She paid back both loans successfully and on time. She hopes to use this current loan to open another business. She will share the loan with her group members, one of whom sells clothing. The other two group members both work in livestock.

loans.use: To open a new business cooking and selling food.

loans.name: Neema

texts.en: Neema has owned a business selling food in Arusha for one year.  She is married with three children, ages 3, 6, and 9.  Every day she works from 6:30am to 10:00pm, which allows her to generate a monthly profit of approximately $150.  Neema is hoping to take out a loan to expand her business and increase her profit.

loans.use: To buy more inventory and expand her business.

loans.name: Doris

texts.en: Doris has been providing secretarial services in Arusha since 2005.  She is married with two children, ages 9 and 13.  She works from 8:00am to 6:00pm every day, which allows her to earn a monthly profit of approximately $70.  This will be Doris's first loan and she will use it to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: To expand her business.

loans.name: Kudura

texts.en:
Kudura is 28 years old and she is married with one 6-year-old child. She began selling clothes and decorations in 2007. Every day, she works from 8am to 9pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Kudura now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes and decorations for her business.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Hanuni

texts.en:
Hanuni is 40 years old. She is a married woman with 7 children, ages between 1 and 20. She became a seller of charcoal and firewood in 2000. Every day, she works at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Hanuni now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal and firewood for her business.

loans.use: To buy more inventory.

loans.name: Yerusolem Group

texts.en:
Anna has owned a business selling clothing in Arusha since 2006. She is married with two children, ages 5 and 7. She works every day from 6:30 am to 7:00 pm, which allows her to earn approximately $50 each month. She is hoping to take out a loan so that she may purchase more items for sale in her shop.

Anna will share this loan with her group member, Nangidare, who owns a shop selling food.

loans.use: To increase inventory.

loans.name: Habibi's Shukrani Group

texts.en:
Habibi is 29 years old. She is a married woman with 3 children aged 12, 10, and 2. She became a tailor and juice seller in 2004. Every day, she works from 7am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Habibi now hopes for a loan to buy more tailoring items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, who also has a business selling juice.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy has had a business selling secretarial services in Arusha for eight years. She is married with two children, ages 5 and 12. She also cares for two dependents who are also 5 and 12 years old. Lucy works from 7:30am to 6:00pm daily to earn a monthly profit of approximately $200 per month.

Lucy has previously taken out two loans through BRAC Tanzania. She paid back both loans successfully and on time. She is hoping to use this current loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand a secretarial business.

loans.name: Rehema's Hidaya Njema Group

texts.en:
Rehema is a married woman with 4 children aged 13, 11, 9, and 5. She began selling charcoal, firewood, and coconuts in 2002. Every day, she works from 7am to 10pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Rehema now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal, firewood, and coconuts for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses selling clothes and bricks.

loans.use: To buy more inventory.

loans.name: Shalom Group

texts.en:
Tatu has owned a business selling vegetables in Arusha since 1999. She is single with two children, ages 11 and 17. She works daily from 8:00am to 6:00pm, which allows her to earn a profit of approximately $30 per month.

Tatu has taken out two previous loans through BRAC Tanzania. She paid back both loans successfully and on time. She hopes to use this current loan to increase her inventory and expand her business. She hopes that doing so will allow her to earn a greater profit. Tatu will share this loan with her group member, Honoraiha, who also sells vegetables in Arusha.

loans.use: To buy more inventory.

loans.name: Evaline's Group

texts.en:
Evaline has sold bananas in Arusha since 2002. She is 48 years old, married, and has three children ages 33, 24, and 18. She works daily from 8:00am to 4:00pm, which allows her to earn a profit of approximately $50 each month.

Evaline hopes to use this loan to grow her business. She will share it with her two group members. One group member, Nai, sells maize and the other, Eliakesia, sells milk.

loans.use: To buy more inventory.

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en:
Patricia E. is 38 years old and married with 3 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo state, Nigeria with her family. She learnt about the sale of women's fabrics from her mother. She started her own business in 1996. She is a LAPO client.

Patricia is requesting a loan in the amount of US$ 1, 200 to buy more women's fabrics for sale. She says thank you to Kiva lenders who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more female wrappers for sale

loans.name: Mwanambashu's Hidaya Njema Group

texts.en:
Mwanambashu is 39 years old, married, and the mother of 4 children ages 20,17,12, and 10. She makes pots and sells juice in a business that she started in 1992. Every day, she works from 7am to 9pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

Mwanambashu now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses dealing with the sale of clothes, charcoal, firewood, and coconuts.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Kidogo's Hidaya Njema Group

texts.en:
Kidogo is 48 years old, married, with 4 children ages 25, 11, 9, and 2. She has been a charcoal and firewood seller since 1998. Every day, she works from 7am to 9pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Kidogo now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal and firewood for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member, who also has business dealing with shop own

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and firewood for her business.

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy O. is 29 years old and married with a child. She lives in Benin City. She sells shoes and bags. She travels to Lagos State to buy shoes and bags and sells them to customers in Benin City. Mercy needs the loan amount of US$ 525 to buy more shoes and bags for sale. Mercy expresses her gratitude to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more shoes and bags for sale

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence T. is 44 years old and married with 3 children. She lives in Benin City with her husband and children. Florence goes to the villages near Benin City to buy palm oil in large quantities and then supplies and sells to retailers in Benin City. She learned this business for 12 months, and she started her own business in 1993. She needs the loan amount of US$ 1, 200 to buy more palm oil for re-sale. She thanks all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more palm oil for sale

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: Eunice K. is 33 years old and married with 4 children. She lives in Benin City. She is a fashion designer. She learned this business for 4 years and she has been designing clothes for the past 11 years. She is a LAPO client. Eunice needs the loan amount of US$ 525 to buy more tailoring materials and clothes for sale. She says thank you to Kiva lenders and Lapo.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring materials and clothes for sale

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose O. is 37 years old and married with 3 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria where she sells weavons (hair extensions) and provisions. Rose O. learned this business for 6 months and has been in this business since 2007. She needs the loan amount of US$ 875 to buy more weavons and provisions for sale. She  says a big thank you to Kiva lenders. She is grateful to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more weavons and provisions for sale

loans.name: Asya's Mwanzo Mgumu Group

texts.en:
Asya is 40 years old, married, and the mother of five children between the ages of 10 and 25. She has been selling bites (snacks) since 2005. Every day, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Asya now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses selling bread, juice, charcoal, and firewood.

loans.use: To buy more inventory.

loans.name: Riziki's Tunajaribu Group

texts.en:
Riziki is 28 years old and a widow with 3 children ages 12, 9, and 4. She has owned a small bakery since 2002. Every day, she works from 4am to 1:30pm at her business.

Riziki now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses selling fish, charcoal, and firewood.

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Patience

texts.en: Patience E. is 43 years old and married with 4 children. She lives in Benin City with her family. She sells provisions and drinks. She learned this business herself. She started this business in 2005. She is a LAPO client. She needs a loan in the amount of US$ 450 to buy more provisions and drinks for sale. With this she hopes to satisfy her customers better.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and drinks for re-sale

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Gloria O. is 38 years old and married with 4 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria with her family. Gloria  sells women's wrappers. Gloria enjoys doing her business. She learned this business for 5 years and she started her own business in 1995. She needs the loan amount of US$ 875 to buy more women's wrappers for sale. Gloria is a LAPO client. She says thank you to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more women's wrappers for sale

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en: Patricia O. is 41 years old and she is married with 6 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells and supplies drinks. She learned this business for 2 years. She started her own business in 2005. She needs the loan amount of US$ 875 to buy more drinks to sell and supply to customers. She expresses her gratitude to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more drinks for sale and supply

loans.name: Zaina's Tunajaribu Group

texts.en:
Zaina is 45 years old, married, and the mother of two children aged 15 and 8. She has been selling clothes, shoes, and chips since 1993. Every day, she works from 7am to 9pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $125 from her sales.

Zaina now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes and shoes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses selling firewood and chips, handbags, and bites (snacks).

loans.use: To increase inventory

loans.name: Seun

texts.en: Seun O. is 35 years old and married to Mr. O..They have 4 children and they live in Benin City.  She runs a patent medicine store (pharmacy) where she sells drugs to people in her community. Seun learned this business for 2 years and she started her own patent medicine store in 2007. She is a LAPO client.  Seun needs the loan amount of US$ 875 to buy more drugs for sale. Seun is happy and she says thank you to Kiva lenders and Lapo.

loans.use: To buy more drugs for sale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Zainab's Muhajirina Group

texts.en:
Zainab is 30 years old, married, and the mother of 5 children aged between 6 and 20. She has been selling clothes and bites (snacks) since 2003. Every day, she works from 7am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $35 from her sales.

Zainab now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who sell firewood, bites, and charcoal.

loans.use: To buy more clothing inventory.

loans.name: Beauty

texts.en: Beauty I. is 40 years old and married with 8 children. She and her family live in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria.  She sells second-hand clothes. She has been in this business since 1990 and she learned this business for 10 months from a friend. She needs the loan amount of US$ 700 to buy more second-hand clothes for re-sale. She says thank you.

loans.use: To buy more second-hand clothes for re-sale

loans.name: Corazón De Jesús Group

texts.es:
Rusilda R., who lives in the Barrio Santa Lucia zone, formed the committee after contacting her friends and neighbors. The committee is comprised of 18 women who live in the same zone. The women partake in different business activities such as clothing sales, foodstuffs, cosmetics, farming, etc. They are requesting a loan in order to purchase clothing, basic need items, and food, among other goods to be sold.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Para la formación del presente comité fue la señora Rusilda R., ella vive en la zona del Barrio Santa Lucia, esta Sra. contacto con sus vecinas y amigas para formar el comité. El comité esta constituido por 18 señoras quienes viven en la misma zona. Las señoras tienen actividades diferentes una de otra, como ser venta de ropas, comestible, cosméticos, granjera etc. Ellas obtienen el crédito para la compra de ropas, artículos de primera necesidad, comidas y otros, para su posterior venta.

loans.use: Purchase clothing, costume jewelry, footwear, chickens, tapioca, soft drinks, basic foodstuff (sugar, flour, noodles, herbs, eggs, bread, etc.)

loans.name: Shola

texts.en:
Shola F. is 42 years old and married with 6 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria with her family. She sells provisions and drinks. She started this business in 1996. Shola needs the loan amount of US$ 1, 025 to buy more provisions and drinks for sale. She is a LAPO client.

Shola desires to stock up her store with provisions and drinks so that she can serve her customers better. She says thank you to Kiva lenders and LAPO micro-finance.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and drinks for re-sale

loans.name: Charity

texts.en: Charity E. is 56 years old. She is a widow with 6 children. She sells bread. She has been able to send her children to school up to secondary school level, and she hopes to send them up to the university level. To Charity, bread business is fine. Hence she is requesting a loan in the amount of US$ 525 to buy more bread for re-sale. This, she said, will help her serve her customers better. She lives in Benin city, Edo State, Nigeria. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more bread for sale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Caro

texts.en: Caro I. is 40 years old and she is a widow with 4 children. She lives in Benin City with her children. She goes out to the villages to buy soup ingredients which she later sells to people in the city. She learned this business for 3 months from a friend. She started her own business in 1996. Caro is a LAPO client. Caro needs the loan amount of US$ 1, 025 to buy more soup ingredients for sale. She says thank you to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more soup ingredients for sale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort O. is 41 years old and she is a widow with 3 children. She lives in Benin City. Comfort learned this business for 6 months from her mother. She needs the loan amount of US$ 525 to buy more local gin for re-sale. Comfort is a LAPO client. She is grateful to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more local gin (Ogogoro) for re-sale

loans.name: Kuña Katupyry Group

texts.es:
Ms. Gregoria R., who lives in the Barrio San Juan zone, formed this committee after contacting her friends and neighbors of the aforementioned zone. The group is comprised of 19 women of the same area. The women partake in different business activities, such as clothing sales, foodstuffs, cosmetics, farming, etc. They are requesting a loan of 300,000 Paraguay Guarani each in order to purchase clothing, basic need items, foodstuffs, and other goods to be sold.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Para la formación del presente comité fue la señora Gregoria R., ella vive en la zona del Barrio San juan, Esta Sra. contacto con sus vecinas y amigas para formar el comité de dicha zona. El comité esta constituido por 19 señoras todas de la misma zona. Las señoras tienen actividades diferentes una de otra, como ser venta de ropas, comestible, cosméticos , granjera etc. Las señoras retiran un crédito de 300.000 C/U. Ellas Obtiene el crédito para la compra de ropas, artículo de primera necesidad, comidas y otros. Para su posterior venta.

loans.use: Purchase clothing, cosmetics, fabric, basic need items, and other goods

loans.name: Uyi

texts.en: Uyi O. is 52 years old and married with 7 children. She lives in Benin City with her family. Uyi sells provisions and drinks. She learned this business for 6 months and started her own business in 1999. She needs the loan amount of US$ 875 to buy more provisions and drinks for re-sale. Uyi is a LAPO client. She expresses her gratitude to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more drinks and provisions for sale

loans.name: Sunday

texts.en: Sunday O. is 66 years old and he is married with 6 children. He lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. Sunday owns an electric saw. He takes the electric saw to a saw mill and cuts wood for his customers. He started this business in 1973. Sunday needs the loan amount of US$ 525 to maintain his electric saw. He is a LAPO client. He is grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To maintain his sawmill machine

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Gran Esfuerzo I Group

texts.en:
CriseL. H. is a 32-year-old woman who lives with her husband and five children (ages 14, 12, 10, 8, and 6) in a small Haitian community called Pringamoza in the eastern province of Hato Mayor in the Dominican Republic. She began a small business selling clothing a year and a half ago and continues to increase her inventory with each loan. CriseL. travels by bus from town to town selling her products to the other small communities in the countryside as many of these rural people do not have the means to travel to town to do their shopping. She has also recently started a little business making and selling breakfast from home in the mornings. She has started these businesses so that she can provide her children with a good education and a comfortable home.

CriseL. is the leader of the 15-person micro-bank group, Gran Esfuerzo. In English, this means `Great Force´. Each of these unique Dominican entrepreneurs unite in solidarity, allowing them to access funding that they would otherwise never be able to receive on their own.

On behalf of CriseL., the Gran Esfuerzo group, and the entire team here at Esperanza International, we thank you for your support with this micro loan!

loans.use: To buy pants, blouses, and shoes

loans.name: Bombe

texts.fr:
Mrs. Bombe S. is a reputable woman who lives in the Senghor development in Thies. She is married and is the mother of 5 children. She has been a shopkeeper for a good many years. She sells grocery products, for example eggs and fruit, and also general merchandise. She is requesting this loan with a view to diversifying her income.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

MADAME BOMBE S. EST UNE BRAVE FEMME QUI HABITE A LA CITE SENGHOR A THIES .ELLE EST MARIEE ET MERE DE CINQ ENFANTS .ELLE FAIT DU PETIT COMMERCE DEPUIS PLUSIEURS ANNEES .ELLE VEND DES DENREES ALIMENTAIRES NOTAMMENT DES OEUFS ;DES FRUITS ET DES PRODUITS DIVERS. C'EST DANS LE BUT DE DIVERSIFIER SES REVENUS QU'ELLE DEMANDE CE PRET.

loans.use:
retailing general merchandise

PETIT COMMERCE DE DIVERSES MARCHANDISES

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for UIMCEC, a partner of Christian Children\'s Fund - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Kuña Katupyry Group

texts.es:
The Kuña Katupyry women’s committee was formed after the disbanding of another group in the zone. Some of the women of that group decided to form a new group because they were too far from the meeting place. Just like all the other groups, they attended four meetings prior to receiving the loan and agreed to the terms and conditions set by the program. 
Upon getting started, 18 women, who each received 300,000.00 Paraguay Guarani, used the funds for their businesses. Many of the members make handicrafts while others have food, drink, or natural remedies businesses, among other activities. The program is currently in its 5th cycle. The group is pleased to work with Fundación Paraguaya and invite the other women in their neighborhood to participate in the program since aside from the loan benefits, they also receive training in order to help their businesses succeed, while their children receive both free music lessons and money saving courses. 
 Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.
El comite de mujeres " Kuña Katupyry", se conformo debido a la desintegracion de un grupo de la zona, un grupo de ese comité decidio conformarse en uno nuevo, ya que ellas se encontraban muy alejadas del lugar de reunión. Al igual que todos los comités asistieron a cuatros reuniones previas al crédito y estuvieron de acuerdo con todas las condiciones ofrecidas por el programa.
 Al iniciar formaron parte del comité 18 señoras que recibieron un crédito de 300.000Gs cada una, que lo destinaron para sus negocios, dentro del comité hay muchas personas que se dedican a la artesanía y otras tienen negocios de ventas de comidas, bebidas, remedios naturales, etc. Actualmente se encuentran en el 5to ciclo del programa, El comité se encuentra muy a gusto trabajando con la Fundación Paraguaya e instan a las demás señoras de su barrio a participar del programa, pues además del beneficio de obtener créditos, las mujeres reciben capacitación para llevar adelante sus negocios y sus hijos reciben educación musical gratuita, educación para el ahorro infantil.

loans.use: Purchase milk, sugar, machinery, thread, sweets, meat, beverages, etc.

loans.name: Mbae´pora Group

texts.es:
The Mba´apora Group was formed thanks to two women who felt the need to help their community because they had many friends and neighbors who really wanted to work and contribute to the family income. They decided to establish a women’s group and attended four meetings prior to receiving the loan. They then requested 300,000.00 Paraguay Guarani each, which was used to expand their businesses and purchase such goods as sugar, bread, machinery, meats, cold meat, dairy, etc. They also purchased goods for footwear, clothing, and fast food businesses, among others. The program is currently in its 2nd cycle, and the loan has increased to 500,000 Guarani each. Five new members have also joined the group. The Mba´apora Group would like to thank Fundación Paraguaya and Kiva for the courage that they are giving to all of these enterprising women.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

El comite Mba´apora se formo gracias a dos señoras que vieron la necesidad de ayudar a su comunidad, ya que tenian muchas vecinas y amigas con muchas ganas de trabajar y aportar al ingreso de sus familias. Decidieron conformarse en un comite de mujeres, asistieron a cuatro reuniones previas al credito y solicitaron 300.000 Gs cada una, que utilizaron para ampliar sus negocios realizando compras de mercaderias como azucar, panificados, maquinarias, productos carnicos y embutidos, lacteos, etc, e inclusive para emprender actividades como venta de calzados y ropas, venta de comidas rapidas, etc. Actualmente se encuentran en el 2do ciclo y han aumentado su credito a 500.000Gs cada una, asi tambien se han incorporado cinco nuevas integrantes. El comité Mba´apora agradece a la Fundacion Paraguaya y a Kiva el valor que les estan dando a todas las mujeres emprendedoras.

loans.use: Purchase milk, sugar, machinery, thread, sweets, beverages, etc.

loans.name: Daouda

texts.fr:
Daouda D. is a young shopkeeper who lives in the Randoulène district of Thies. He is single and has no children, and he has been tending shop for more than 8 years. For the past two years he has been active in IMCEC Thies, taking out loans that he has reimbursed in a timely manner. He is requesting this loan with a view to bolstering his inventory.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

DAOUDA D. est un jeune commerçant qui vit au quartier randoulène à thies .il est célibataire sans enfants et exerce sa profession depuis plus de 8 ans.ilest sociétaire à IMCEC THIES depuis deux ans et prend des prets qu'il rembourse régulièrement.c'est dans le but de renforcer ses stocks de marchandises qu'il sollicite ce pret.

loans.use:
sale of grocery products

VENTE DE DENREES ALIMENTAIRES

loans.name: Mevlida

texts.en:
Mevlida is a 25-year-old woman from the small community of Osijek, which is located outside the city of Sarajevo. She is single, and currently lives with her parents. Mevlida has been working to support herself at a coffee shop she runs with her friend. They run this shop at the major open market in town, so it gets a lot of business.

Mevlida is requesting this her 1st loan with Zene za Zene in the amount of 1200 KM to help with some renovations to her shop. She would also like to purchase some more goods for her cafe, including coffee & juice, with the remainder of this loan. It is Melvlida’s goal to increase her income by serving more customers after this expansion.

loans.use: To renovate & buy inventory for her cafe

loans.name: Mujeres De Esperanza Group

texts.en:
Sonia M. is a hard-working 63 year old woman living in Puerto Plata, Dominican Republic. She has three sons who are all married and lives with her husband, Luis D. L. Rosa. She will use this loan to open a small clothing shop. She will go to the near by city of Santiago and buy pants, shirts, blouses, undergarments, and shoes. Sonia hopes that her business will be successful enough to one have her own business and a house for her sons.

Sonia M. is part of a 10-person micro-bank, Mujeres D. Esperanza, which means “Esperanza’s Women”. Each woman has their own personal business but they unite to pay their loan as a group. The purpose of the group loan is to assist each other in case someone defaults. The Kiva loans will be divided among the group to pay back.

We thank you for your support on behalf of Sonia, the Mujeres D. Esperanza group, and the entire team at Esperanza International.

loans.use: Sonia Milanes will use this loan to buy pants, shirts, blouses, and undergarments from the nearby city of Santiago.

loans.name: Mujeres Virtuosas Group

texts.es:
The women’s group “Virtuous Women,” was formed thanks to a committee in the same area that helped form this group. There were four meetings before the loan in which 16 women participated, all of whom agreed to the conditions of the program, and whose businesses were formed thanks to a 300,000 GS loan that each has received on the part of the Paraguayan Foundation and Kiva. They actually find themselves in their fifth cycle and during all of those months that they have related to the Paraguayan Foundation family, it has converted itself into one of the best women’s committees in the area. In this cycle each one has received loans of between 300,000 and 1.2 million Gs. The committee is actually formed of 17 sacrificing women, and the majority of them are the heads of their households, and because of this are very thankful to the Paraguayan Foundation for having given them the opportunity to raise and help their families.

Translated from Spanish by Zach Frey, Kiva volunteer.

El comite de mujeres " Mujeres Virtuosas", se conformo gracias a un comite de la misma zona quienes ayudaron a conformar el grupo. Se realizaron cuatro reuniones previas al credito en donde participaron 16 señoras de las cuales toas estuvieron de acuerdo con las condiciones del programa, y cuyos negocios fueron creciendo gracias al credito de 300.000GS cada una que han recibido por parte de Fundacion Paraguaya y Kiva. Actualmente se encuentran en el 5to ciclo y durante todos estos meses que han pertenecido a la gran familia de la Fundacion Paraguaya se han convertido en uno de los mejores comités de mujeres de la zona. En este ciclo cada una han recibido creditos de entre 300.000 Gs y 1.200.000Gs. El comite actualmente esta conformado por 17 señoras muy sacrificadas y la mayoria de ellas son cabeza de familia es por eso que agradecen mucho a la Fundacion Paraguaya por haberles dado la oportunidad de crecer y ayudar a sus familias.

loans.use: Purchase of milk, vegetables, needles, cloth, and other merchandise

loans.name: Bahrija

texts.en:
Bahrija is a 31-year-old woman living in Sarajevo. She is divorced, and is raising her seven-year-old on her own. Bahrija makes a living running a bistro, a small restaurant where she sells an assortment of coffee and light meals. She also receives a small welfare allowance for her child in the amount of 50 KM a month.

This is her first loan with Zene za Zene, and she has requested 1200 KM to purchase some supplies for her restaurant. She will spend this loan mostly on food, and it is her hope to increase her business by offering some new meals at her restaurant.

loans.use: To buy some more inventory for her restaurant

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose E. is 32 years old and married with a child. She lives in Benin City. Rose is a fashion designer. She designs women's clothes. She acquired this skill of fashion design over a period of 3 years and 6 months. She started her own fashion home in 1999. She needs the loan amount of US$ 875 to buy more female wrappers and tailoring materials for re-sale. Rose is a LAPO client. She says thank you to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more female wrappers and tailoring materials for re-sale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Pabla

texts.es:
Pabla, 52, is married and has 3 grown children, all of whom are college graduates.

Pabla has been a biochemist for more than 20 years. Currently, she is the owner of a small pharmacy located in a middle-class, well-established neighborhood.

Pabla tells us that she married at a very young age, and from early on she had to juggle her duties as a wife and mother with her profession and other jobs. At that time, she worked as a house maid, but this job gave her little time to spend with her young family. With great effort, Pabla and her husband, who is a doctor, were able to save some money and invested it to open a pharmacy sixteen years ago.

In their pharmacy, Pabla offers good prices, a good variety of products and personalized attention to her customers. Pabla is requesting a loan to buy medicine lots of various kinds: cold medicine, antibiotics, and medicines imported from abroad.

Translated by Maria B., Kiva volunteer

La Sra. Pabla tiene 52 años de edad, esta casada, tiene 3 hijos, todos ellos mayores y profesionales.

La Sra. Pabla es bioquímica se dedica a esta profesión hace más de 20 años, Actualmente es propietaria de una farmacia en un barrio bastante poblado y habitado por personas de un nivel económico medio.

Comenta la Sra. Pabla que se casó bastante joven y ejerció su profesión dividiéndose con la educación de sus hijos y su trabajo, en esa época era empleada doméstica en una casa y su actividad le daba poco tiempo para su familia. Con esfuerzo y con la ayuda de su marido que es médico, invierteron un capital ahorrado y abrieron una Farmacia que hoy día ya posee 16 años de antigüedad.

Ofrece buenos precios, variedad en productos y una atención personalizada a sus clientes. Ella hoy solicita el préstamo para la compra de lotes de medicamentos varios tales como: antigripales, antibióticos, medicamentos de procedencia extranjera entre otros.

loans.use: Compra de lotes de medicamentos varios tales como: antigripales , antibióticos, medicamentos de procedencia extranjera entre otros.

loans.name: Kenneth

texts.en:
Kenneth A. is 25 years old and married with 2 children. He lives in Benin City with his family. He sells handsets and recharge cards. He has been in this business since 2006. He learned this business for 2 months from a friend.

Kenneth is requesting a loan in the amount of US$ 1, 200 to buy more handsets and recharge cards for sale. Kenneth is a LAPO client. He expresses his gratitude to all who make this possible.

loans.use: To buy more mobile phones and recharge cards for re-sale

loans.name: Beauty

texts.en: Beauty I. is 36 years old and married with 4 children. She lives in Benin City, Edo State. Beauty buys table water from dealers in bulk and then she supplies the table water to retailers. She has been in this business since 2001. She learned this business from a friend. She needs the loan amount of US$ 875 to buy more table water for supplies and for sale. She says thank you to all.

loans.use: To buy more table water for distribution to retailers

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en: Mercy O. is 38 years old and married with 5 children. She lives in Benin City,  Edo State, Nigeria. She sells plantains wholesale. She travels to the villages nearby Benin City to buy plantains wholesale. She later sells the plantains to retailers who in turn sell them to the final consumers. She needs the loan amount of US$ 875 to buy more plantains to meet the demands of her customers. She is grateful to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more plantains for re-sale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Johnbull

texts.en: Johnbull O. is 44 years old and married with 4 children. He is lives in Benin City. He specializes in the installation and repair of streetlights. He learned this business for 7 years.He started his own business in 2000. Johnbull needs the loan amount of US$ 525 to buy more electrical materials to enhance his business. Johnbull is a LAPO client and he expresses his gratitude to all who make the loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more electrical materials for his business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Gran Esfuerzo Ii Group

texts.en:
Miguel M. (pictured in the front in the blue hat) is a 44-year-old single father who lives with his five children (ages 18, 16, 8, 6, and 4) in a small Haitian community called Pringamoza in the eastern province of Hato Mayor in the Dominican Republic. His wife died a couple of years ago and he has since begun a small business selling miscellaneous items such as charcoal, calling cards, and candy so that he can be flexible and more easily available to his children.  Miguel sells these items from his home as well as in the streets.  He has started these businesses so that he can provide his children with a good education and a comfortable home.  

Miguel is the leader of the 15-person micro-bank group, Gran Esfuerzo.  In English, this means `Great Force´.  Each of these unique Haitian entrepreneurs unite in solidarity, allowing them to access funding that they would otherwise never be able to receive on their own. 

On behalf of Miguel, the Gran Esfuerzo group, and the entire team here at Esperanza International, we thank you for your support with this micro loan!

loans.use: To buy charcoal, cell phone calling cards, and candy

loans.name: Mercy

texts.en:
Mercy S. sells bananas and plantains. She is married, but her husband's income as a carpenter is not sufficient for Mercy and her child. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Dorcas

texts.en: Dorcas I. is 50 years old and she is a widow with 7 children. She lives in Benin City with her family. She sells drinks and foodstuffs for a living. Dorcas has been in this business since 1996. She learned this business for 6 months, finding out how to sell drinks and foodstuffs. Dorcas needs the loan amount of US$ 875 to buy more foodstuffs and drinks for sale. She is a LAPO client. She says thank you.

loans.use: To buy more drinks and foodstuffs for sale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Paul

texts.en: Paul O. is 42 years old, married with 4 children. He lives in Benin City with his family. He moulds blocks for the building of houses. He learned this business for 3 years and he started his own business in 2004. Paul has one molding machine and with this he is not able to meet the demands of his increasing number of customers. So, he needs the loan amount of US$ 1, 200 to buy one molding machine to enhance his production. He is a LAPO client

loans.use: To buy one molding machine for the production of blocks for sale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en: Felicia O. is 40 years old and married with 5 children. She lives in Benin City where she runs a business selling provisions and drinks.
