loans.name: Parveen

texts.en: Parveen baji is the wife of M. R., and they have a chemical supply business.  At their chemical factory, they create supplies for medicine and packaging.  Parveen baji lives in an area named Yadgar (famous historical place) in Lahore, Pakistan. She is the mother of seven children: six sons and one daughter. Her eldest son who is 21 years old helps his father in his chemical business. The next eldest son makes shoe soles on order. Her younger sons and her one daughter are enrolled in a local school in her area. Parveen baji is a housewife and also makes shoe soles on order. Parveen baji successfully completed two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is requesting a loan to buy materials (Zinc, Alum) for her husband so that he can extend his chemical supply business.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her chemical factory

loans.name: Sugran

texts.en: Sugran baji is the wife of M. A. and has a sugarcane juice business. Sugran baji has been living in an area named Yadgar (a famous historical place) in Lahore for the last 20 years. Her husband M. A. sells sugarcane juice and has been in this profession for the last 25 years. Sugran baji currently has two juice machines running. She is the mother of nine children: four sons and five daughters. All of her sons sell sugarcane juice in different places. Her elder daughter sews clothes. Her younger daughters are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood.  Sugran baji successfully completed three loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan), with all payments on time. Now she is requesting a loan to buy materials (motor engine, generator and wheel) for a new sugarcane juice machine, so that she can expand her business.

loans.use: To buy machinery for her sugarcane juice business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in fashionable jewelry and move her business forward

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación San Miguel Arcángel, Inc. (FSMA) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase goods to restock a small grocery store

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación San Miguel Arcángel, Inc. (FSMA) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To invest in vegetables and fruits to retail in her community.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación San Miguel Arcángel, Inc. (FSMA) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Fidan

texts.en: Fidan (her father is pictured) was born in 1987. She is single. The Huseynov family lives in Baku city. This family has been in the cafe business for three years. Now they need a loan of $1200 to buy glasses, teapots, kettles and sugar bowls to improve their business..

loans.use: To buy glasses, teapots, kettles and sugar bowls

loans.name: Tursunoy

texts.en:
T. Tursunoy is 48 years old. She is separated from her husband and raising her son alone. She began her business to keep herself busy and active when she found herself sad and depressed due to her separation, as well as to have an independent income. Having only one son, she is doing her best to make him well-educated and happy.

Tursunoy is a market vendor. She is selling clothes for kids. As a rule, she travels to the neighboring city to purchase the goods with the help of her son. In general, her business is stable and has strong potential for further development. However, Tursunoy stresses that after loans provided by the International Micro-Loan Fund IMON, she managed to accelerate the development of her business considerably. For instance with one of the loans, Tursunoy rented one more trading place in the market.

Today she is planning to increase her working capital in order to expand her business. For this purpose she requests 800 USD for the term of 12 months. Tursunoy promises to mange the current loan with accuracy as she did all the previous ones and thanks everyone for supporting her.

loans.use: Increase working capital to develop her business.

loans.name: Farhod

texts.en:
K. Farhod is 28 years old. He is a loving husband and father, and for a long time has been running a grocery store which he rents. Farhod began his own store with his hard-earned savings as he had always wanted to be an entrepreneur. He has been selling fruits, vegetables and different kinds of foodstuffs in his grocery store for the past 7 years. During these years Farhod acquired the knowledge and skills required for the business. Vegetable and fruits sales are flourishing for the simple reason that every home needs vegetables.

His wife Amina helps Farhod with the business. They were able to make it grow and they want to turn it into a great success. Since he started their store, he was able to increase its clientele and in order to provide them with good service. He is requesting a loan of 950 USD for the term of 12 months, which he will use to buy merchandise to increase his assortment. With your help, this will be possible.

loans.use: Increasing of the range of goods

loans.name: Thi Ninh's Group

texts.vi:
Ms Tô thị Ninh is 49 years old. She likes participating in SEDA program. She raises livestock. She is requesting a loan of 2.950.000 VND. She also provides opportunities for others T. profit from her family business as well. Her family income is 150.000 VND a day. Her group is composed of:

  • Ms Dương thị Văn who's requesting 2.950.000 VND T. invest in her plastic recycling business.
  • Mr Lưu văn Thạch who's requesting 2.950.000 VND. He sells fruits & flowers
  • Ms Kiều thị Châm MS who's requesting 2.950.000 VND. She sells fruits & flowers
  • Ms Đinh thị Xuân MS who's requesting 2.950.000 VND. She collects & sells waqste material.
  • Mr Nguyễn văn Hùng who's requeswting 2.950.000 VND. He raises livestock

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer.

    Cô Tô thị Ninh năm nay 49 tuổi,MS 030021 Cô rất thích tham gia vay vốn của chương trình.Ngoài việc chăn nuôi,Cô còn vay vốn với mức 2.950.000 VND để hỗ trợ cho việc mua ngô về để nổ bỏng,cô còn tạo ra nhiều việc làm cho các chị em khác trong thôn có thêm thu nhập từ công việc sản xuất của gia đình cô.Mức thu nhập bình quân của gia đình từ 150.000 VND / ngày.Trong nhóm cô còn có

  • chị Dương thị Văn MS 030022 vay mức 2.950.000 VND để kinh doanh đồ nhựa
  • anh Lưu văn Thạch MS 030024 vay mức 2.950.000 VND về làm bỏng miến và đi chợ buôn hoa quả
  • chị Kiều thị Châm MS 030025 vay mức 2.950.000 VND để buôn hoa quả
  • chị Đinh thị Xuân MS 030026 vay mức 2.950.000 VND để kinh doanh sắt vụn
  • anh Nguyễn văn Hùng MS 030027 vay mức 2.950.000 VND để chăn nuôi

loans.use: raise livestock

loans.name: Ajdar

texts.en: Ajdar has been in this business for 20 years. He was born in 1957. He lives in Baku city, Novkhani village. He is married and has 3 children. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy fertilizer and seedlings to improve his greenhouse.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seedlings

loans.name: Lamina

texts.en: Lamina (her brother is pictured) is a widow with the one child. She was born in 1946. The Aliyev's family lives in Baku city, Mashtaga settlement. Lamina has been in the dairy business for 6 years. Now she needs a loan of $1200 to buy a cow.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Thi Hoa's Group

texts.vi:
Ms Nguyễn thị Hoa is 39 years old. She likes SEDA program very much because the loan condition is easy and it suits her condition. She is requesting a loan of 3.186000 VND to have capital to start a retail business. Her family combined income is 150.000 VND a day. Her group is composed of:

  • Ms C. thị Thuần, requesting 3.186000 VND. She sells rice
  • Ms C. thị Ba MS, requesting 2.006000 VND. She makes rice gallettes.
  • MsNguyễn thị Hợi, requesting 2.006000 VND. She sells basic goods.
  • Ms Dương thị Hồng, requesting 3.186000 VND. She sells clothes
  • Ms Đặng thị Hường, requesting 3.186000 VND. She sells clothes

    • Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva Volunteer.

    cchị Nguyễn thị Hoa năm nay 39 tuổi,MS13040007.Chị rất thích tham gia vay vốn của chương trình vì thấy rất thuận tiện ,mức trả lại phù hợp với gia đình Chị.Lần này Chị đăng ký vay ở mức 3.186000 VND để buôn bán và lấy vốn để kinh doanh .Mỗi ngày gia đình Chị thu nhập được khoảng 150.000 VND.Nhóm Chị gồm có các thành viên :

  • chị C. thị Thuần MS 13040008 vay mức vốn là 3.186000 VND để buôn gạo
  • chị C. thị Ba MS 13040009 vay ở mức vốn 2.006000 VND để lấy vốn tráng bánh đa nem
  • chị Nguyễn thị Hợi MS 13040010 vay mức 2.006000 VND để đi chợ
  • chị Dương thị Hồng MS 13040011 vay ở mức 3.186000 VND để kinh doanh quần áo
  • chị Đặng thị Hường MS 13040012 vay mức 3.186000 VND để buôn bán quần áo

loans.use: retails

loans.name: Zena's Malaika Group

texts.en:
Zena is a 21-year-old, married woman with one 2-year-old child. In addition, she takes care of two other people who are 13 and 18 years old. For a living, she sells food and clothing. Every day, she works extremely hard from 8 am to 6 pm at her business and, in doing so, she can earn a monthly profit of approximately $90 from her sales.

Zena now seeks a loan in order to buy more rice, maize, flour, meat, vegetables, bananas, and clothes for her business. Notably, she will share the loan proceeds with her subgroup members, Halima, Zainabu, Shamila, and Sauda, who have their own sales businesses dealing with food, charcoal, soap, and clothing.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by increasing inventory (i.e., by purchasing additional food and clothes)

loans.name: Joyce's Jiamini Group

texts.en:
Joyce is a single woman with 2 children who are 1 and 4 years old. She began selling fish and soap in 2008. Every day, she works extremely hard from 8 am to 5 pm at her business and, in doing so, she can earn a monthly profit of approximately $155 from her sales.

Joyce now seeks a loan in order to buy more fish and soap for her business. Importantly, she will share the loan proceeds with her subgroup members, Tatu, Maria, and Amina, who have their own businesses dealing with secretarial services and clothing sales.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by purchasing additional fish and soap

loans.name: Ummy's Neema Group

texts.en:
Ummy is a 42-year-old, married woman with 4 children who are 20, 17, 14, and 10 years old. She owns and operates a mill machine, and she started this business in 2003. Every day, she works extremely hard from 8 am to 6 pm at her business and, in doing so, she can earn a monthly profit of approximately $40 from her sales.

Ummy now seeks a loan in order to buy more items for her business. Notably, she will share the loan proceeds with her subgroup member, Tatu.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by increasing her inventory (i.e., by purchasing additional items)

loans.name: Judith's Tunda Group

texts.en:
Judith is a married woman with 2 children who are 20 and 2 years old. She owns and operates a small shop which sells various household products and which was started in 2006. Every day, she works extremely hard from 6 am to 10 pm at her business and, in doing so, she can earn a monthly profit of approximately $350 from her sales.

Judith now seeks a loan in order to buy more items for her business. Notably, she will share the loan proceeds with her subgroup members, Maua and Mwanaisha, who have their own businesses selling clothes.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by increasing her inventory (i.e., by purchasing additional items)

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Ester is a 48-year-old, married woman with 4 children who are 23, 20, 14, and 12 years old. She began selling clothes in 1998. Every day, she works extremely hard from 10 am to 3 pm at her business and, in doing so, she can earn a monthly profit of approximately $40 from her sales.

Ester now requests a loan in order to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by purchasing additional clothes

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a 23-year-old, married woman with 2 children who are 9 and 4 years old. She began selling clothes in 2005. Every day, she works extremely hard from 8 am to 8 pm at her business and, in doing so, she can earn a monthly profit of approximately $90 from her sales.

Joyce now seeks a loan in order to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by purchasing additional clothes

loans.name: Happy

texts.en:
Happy is a married woman with one 3-year-old child . She began selling clothes in 2007. Every day, she works extremely hard from 9 am to 6 pm at her business and, in doing so, she can earn a monthly profit of approximately $175 from her sales.

Happy now seeks a loan in order to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by purchasing additional clothes

loans.name: Brigther's Upendo B Group

texts.en:
Brigther is a married woman with 4 children who are 11, 9, 6, and 3 years old. She owns and operates a small food vending store, which she started in 2007. Every day, she works extremely hard from 8 am to 5 pm at her business and, in doing so, she can earn a monthly profit of approximately $250 from her sales.

Brigther now requests a loan in order to buy more food items, such as rice, maize, flour, meat, vegetables, and bananas for her business. Importantly, she will share the loan proceeds with her subgroup members, Hamida and Scola, who have their own businesses in clothing sales and food sales.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by purchasing additional food

loans.name: Melesiana's Upendo B Group

texts.en:
Melesiana is a single woman with 2 children who are 18 and 6 years old. She began selling beans in 2003. Every day, she works extremely hard from 6:30 am to 7:30 pm at her business and, in doing so, she can earn a monthly profit of approximately $70 from her sales.

Melesiana now seeks a loan in order to buy more beans for her business. Notably, she will share the loan proceeds with her subgroup member, Rose, who has her own business selling vegetables.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by purchasing additional beans

loans.name: Neema John's Red Rose Group

texts.en:
Neema J., age 38, is single and has two children (ages 10 and 2 1/2). She sells food from 8 AM to 4 PM daily and earns a profit of about $431 a month.

In the past, Neema repaid two loans from Tujijenge Tanzania, which she used to increase her business. She is requesting a new loan to pay her daughter's school fees and purchase more cereals to sell. She will share this loan with the seven other members of her Red Rose group. These members hold each other accountable for repaying their loans.

In the picture, Neema is the second person from the left in the orange dress.

loans.use: Pay school fees for her daughter and to increase stock of cereals to sell

loans.name: Aisha's Msimamo Group

texts.en:
Aisha is a single woman with 2 children who are 10 and 6 years old. She began selling clothes in 2007. Every day, she works extremely hard from 8 am to 6 pm at her business and, in doing so, she can earn a monthly profit of approximately $125 from her sales.

Aisha now requests a loan in order to buy more clothes for her business. Notably, she will share the loan proceeds with her subgroup members, Agatha and Subira, who have their own businesses selling food.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by purchasing additional clothes.

loans.name: Sada's Kambaya Group

texts.en:
Sada is a 26-year-old, married woman with 2 children who are 8 and 6 years old. She began selling clothes in 2008. Every day, she works extremely hard from 7 am to 6 pm at her business and, in doing so, she can earn a monthly profit of approximately $30 from her sales.

Sada now seeks a loan in order to buy more clothes for her business. Importantly, she will share the loan proceeds with her subgroup member, Rose, who has her own business selling groceries.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by purchasing additional clothes

loans.name: Munyandekwe

texts.en:
Greetings from Nyamata in Rwanda! F. is 28 years old and single with one adopted
orphan from the 1994 genocide. 


In 2003, MUNYANDEKWE, F. started his business after getting a loan of $100 from Vision Finance Company. He sells beans, sorghum, and cassava flour in his small shop. He earns about $80 every month.  He employs two people to help him run the business. He is requesting a loan of 20,4655 Frws to expand his business.

loans.use: Expand his business.

loans.name: Jemaida's Kambaya Group

texts.en:
Jemaida is a 26-year-old, married woman with one 2-year-old child. She owns and operates a small grocery store, which she started in 2008. Every day, she works extremely hard from 7 am to 4 pm at her business and, in doing so, she can earn a monthly profit of approximately $20 from her sales.

Jemaida now requests a loan in order to buy more grocery items for her business. Notably, she will share the loan proceeds with her subgroup member, Hadija, who has her own business selling charcoal.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by purchasing additional groceries

loans.name: Zena

texts.en:
Zena is a 28-year-old, married woman with 2 children who are 7 and 4 years old. She began selling clothes in 1997. Every day, she works extremely hard from 6 am to 4 pm at her business and, in doing so, she can earn a monthly profit of approximately $55 from her sales.

Zena now seeks a loan in order to buy more clothes at wholesale prices (i.e., in bulk) for her business.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by purchasing additional clothes in bulk

loans.name: Ayirwanda

texts.en:
Greetings from Nyamata in Rwanda! G. is 41 years old, married with 2 children and one adopted child from the 1994 genocide. 


In 2004, G. started a small shop worth $100 after acquiring a loan from Vision Finance Company. He acquired a loan from VFC and sells different items in the shop like soap, beans, vouchers, salt and all domestic items. He employs two people in his business and makes about $100 per month. He is requesting a loan of 300,000 Frws to buy more stock for his shop.


AYIRWANDA G. is the man in blue & white t-shirt; the others are his clients.

loans.use: Increase his working capital

loans.name: Asia's Motomoto Group

texts.en:
Asia is a 35-year-old, married woman with 4 children who are 19, 17, 15, and 12 years old. She began selling fish in 2006. Every day, she works hard from 8 am to 12 pm at her business and, in doing so, she can earn a monthly profit of approximately $25 from her sales.

Asia now requests a loan in order to buy more fish for her business. Importantly, she will share the loan proceeds with her subgroup members, Bahati and Joyce, who also have businesses dealing with charcoal sales and food sales.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by purchasing additional fish

loans.name: Fatuma's Motomoto Group

texts.en:
Fatuma is a 34-year-old, married woman with 2 children (aged 13 and 2 years old). She began selling foods in 2008. Every day, she works from 1 am to 6 pm at her business and, in doing so, she can earn a monthly profit of approximately $18 from her sales.

Fatuma now requests a loan in order to buy more food items, such as rice, maize, flour, meat, vegetables, and bananas for her business. Notably, she will share the loan proceeds with her subgroup members, Zubeda and Magreth, who also have businesses dealing with poultry and fish sales.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by purchasing additional food items

loans.name: Noriniso

texts.en:
Noriniso R.  was born in 1951 in the Kairakkum region of Tajikistan. She is a single mother but she is full of enthusiasm. She has been a client of MicroInvest since 2008. She first applied to MicroInvest because she was in a difficult financial situation but thanks to the previous loan she was able to improve the situation and develop her existing business. 

Mrs. Noriniso R.  is engaged in selling fruit. She sells fruit she grows herself so she manages to have low prices and repeat customers. Mrs. Noriniso R.  is applying to KIVA requesting a loan in the amount of of 1100 STJ for 5 months with a view to extending and developing her business.

loans.use: business development

loans.name: Hadija's Motomoto Group

texts.en:
Hadija is a 29-year-old, divorced woman with 3 children (aged 13, 9 and 3 years old). She began selling food in 2007. Every day, she works from 6 am to 11 pm at her business and, in doing so, she can earn a monthly profit of approximately $125 from her sales.

Hadija now seeks a loan in order to buy more food items, such as rice, maize, flour, meat, vegetables, and bananas for her business. Importantly, she will share the loan proceeds with her subgroup member, Monica , who also has a food sales business.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by purchasing additional food

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en:
Naomi is a single woman who began selling clothes in 2002. Every day, she works extremely hard from 11 am to 5 pm at her business.

Naomi now requests a loan in order to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by purchasing additional clothes

loans.name: Khursheda

texts.en:
Khursheda R. has been an active client of MicroInvest since 2002. She is a hard-working and non-problem client. She trusts the MicroInvest loan procedures so she applies regularly to MicroInvest. Mrs. Khursheda R. lives in the B.Gafurov region and she is married. Having 2 pretty children, she dreams of a happy future for them.

Mrs. Khursheda R. sells children's and women's wear in the local bazaar where she has a stall. She has direct suppliers so she sells at prices that are lower than the bazaar prices. She wants to import new seasonal goods. Mrs. R. Khursheda is applying to KIVA for financial support, for a loan in the amount of 4100 STJ for 6 months for business development.

loans.use: business development

loans.name: Mavluda

texts.en:
Mavluda S. was born in 1962 in the B.Gafurov region of Tajikistan. She is married and has 3 children. She has been an active client of MicroInvest since 2002. She is a hard-working and non-problem client. She trusts the MicroInvest loan procedures so she applies regularly to MicroInvest.

Mrs. Mavluda S. is engaged in commerce. She has a stall in the local bazaar where she sells garments. She is asking KIVA for a business development loan in the amount of 1600 STJ for 5 months to buy new imported seasonal goods and increase her turnover.

loans.use: buying new seasonal goods

loans.name: Sada's Tujuane Group

texts.en:
Sada is a 25-year-old, married woman with 2 children. One of her children is 7 years old, while the other child is 1 years old. She has been a trader since in 2006. Every day, she works from 7 am to 6 pm at her business and, in doing so, she can earn a monthly profit of approximately $25 from her sales.

Sada now seeks a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses dealing with soft drinks sales, medical supply sales, and bites sales.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by purchasing additional items

loans.name: Marhabo

texts.en:
Marhabo S.  has been a client of MicroInvest since 2008. She first applied to MicroInvest for a business development loan and thanks to the previous loan she was able to increase her business turnover. Now she has opened a stall in the Kairakkum bazaar selling vegetables. She sells the various sorts of vegetables that are grown in her garden. She works hard in the garden so she likes the business she is engaged in. 

Mrs. S. is applying to KIVA for a business support loan of 2200 STJ for 6 months for importing seeds  and increasing the area of her garden.

loans.use: importing seeds and increasing the area of her market garden

loans.name: Harambee Group

texts.en:
For two years, Angela has owned and operated a shop in Arusha, where she sells clothes. She is 27 years old, married, and has one young child. She works daily from 8:00 am to 10:00 pm, which enables her to make a profit of approximately $60 each month. Angela is hoping to take out this loan so that she can purchase more clothing at bulk rates to sell from her store. By improving and expanding her business, she hopes to increase her profits.

Angela has previously taken out two loans from BRAC Tanzania, both of which she promptly and successfully paid back. She will be sharing the loan proceeds with her fellow group member, Eline, who owns and operates a shop of her own in Arusha.

loans.use: To improve and expand her business by purchasing additional clothing in bulk.

loans.name: Mavluda

texts.en:
Mavluda U.  has been an active client of MicroInvest since 2002 and is a serious client. She trusts us and we trust her since she has not had any problems with previous loan repayment. Mrs. U. lives in Khujand. She is married and has 5 children She sells men's and children's wear. She works with direct suppliers so she is able to sell at low prices. She has repeat customers and good turnover. 

Mrs. U.  wants to import new goods so she is asking for a KIVA business development loan of 2600 STJ for 4 months to develop her business and import new seasonal wear.

loans.use: importing new seasonal wear

loans.name: Happy's Tujikomboe Group

texts.en:
Happy is a married woman with 2 children, ages 8 and 5. She has owned a small general store since 2007. She works from 7am to 6pm at her business everyday and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Happy now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Fatuma, Laurencia, Watende, and Rahima.

loans.use: To increase her inventory.

loans.name: Mariamu's Tujuane Group

texts.en:
Mariamu is 32 years old, married, and has 5 children between the ages of 2 and 16. She became a charcoal seller in 2000. She works from 8am to 7pm at her business everyday and can earn a monthly profit of about $110 from her sales.

Mariamu now hopes for a loan to buy more charcoal for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses dealing with food and clothing sales.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal for her business.

loans.name: Changamoto Group

texts.en:
Ida has been selling maize in Arusha since 1985. She is 47 years old, married, and has five children, ages 26, 22, 18, 14, and 8. She also cares for three dependents, ages 32, 24, and 18. She works every day from 10:00am to 5:00pm which allows her to generate a monthly profit of approximately $50. She hopes that this loan will allow her to increase her inventory and expand her business.

Ida will be sharing this loan with her fellow group members Anna, Sarah, Gladness, and Juliana. Each member also owns her own shop in Arusha.

loans.use: To buy more maize to expand her business.

loans.name: Salama

texts.en:
Salama is 32 years old, married, and has 3 children, ages 15, 14 and 3. She has owned a small food vending store since 2004. She works from 6am to10pm at her business everyday and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Salama now hopes for a loan to buy more food items such as rice, maize flour, meat, vegetables, and bananas for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items to increase her stock.

loans.name: Abdurasul

texts.en:
Abdurasul U.  is 26 years old, and he is married and has 2 children. He works in a diagnostic center for mobile telephone repair. He has 5 years work experience and now he plans to modernize his existing business to use up-to-date technologies. 

Mr. U.  is applying to KIVA for financial support through a business development loan of 2100 STJ for 5 months for purchasing a new computer.

loans.use: purchasing a new computer

loans.name: Asha's Group

texts.en:
Asha has been selling vegetables in Arusha since 1999. She is single with no children. Everyday, Asha works from 8:00am to 6:00pm which allows her to earn a monthly profit of approximately $20. Asha is hoping to take out this loan so that she may expand her business and increase her profits.

Asha will be sharing this loan with her fellow group member, Matilda, who also sells food in Arusha.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables to expand her business.

loans.name: Nasra Rehman's Tumaini Letu Group

texts.en:
Nasra Rahman, age 32, is married and has three children (ages 11, 9, and 6). She has a clothing shop that she started in 1999. She works from 8 AM to 8 PM daily, and is able to make a profit of about $172 a month.

In the past, she has had 4 loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to buy land. She is requesting a new loan so she can open a salon. Nasra will share this loan with her loan group, called Tumaini Letu, which has 19 members. These members hold each other accountable for paying back their loans.

In the picture, Nasra is the second person from the left, in an orange blouse.

loans.use: Open a new salon

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is 31 years old, married, and has 3 children, ages 9, 7, and 1. She became a clothing seller in 2004. She works from 8am to 10pm at her business everyday and can earn a monthly profit of about $60 from her sales.

Judith now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Fatuma's Tumaini Group

texts.en:
Fatuma is 40 years old, married, and has 3 children, ages 21, 26, and 17. She is also the caretaker of one other child who is 5 years old. She has owned a small general store since 2005. She works from 8am to 8:30pm at her business everyday and can earn a monthly profit of about $165 from her sales.

Fatuma now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who own cafes, shops, and food businesses.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora has been selling milk in Arusha since 2001. She is married and has four children, ages 5, 11, 18, and 22. She also has two dependents in her care: a 5-year-old and an 11-year-old. She works daily from 6:00am to 6:00pm and is able to earn a profit of approximately $30 each month.

Flora has taken out two previous loans from BRAC Tanzania with which she bought more cows. She paid both back successfully and on time. She now wants to take out this loan so that she can buy more food for her animals. By feeding them better, they will hopefully produce more milk and give her more to sell.

loans.use: To buy more food for her cows.

loans.name: Mahbubahon

texts.en:
Mahbubahon U. has been an active client of MicroInvest since 2002 and is known to be a serious client. She trusts us and we trust her, since she has not any delinquencies or other problems with repayment of previous loans. Mrs. U. lives in Khujand. She is married and has 4 children. She sells stationery. She works with direct suppliers so she sells at low prices. She has repeat customers and good turnover.

Mrs. U. wants to import new goods so she is asking Kiva for a business development loan of 4100 somoni for 3 months to expand her business and import new goods for resale.

loans.use: Business development and importing new goods

loans.name: Courage

texts.en: Courage A. is 35 years old and married with 5 children. She lives in Benin City. She sells provisions and drinks.  Courage learnt this business for 2 years and she started her own business in 1992. She needs the loan amount of US$ 875 to buy more provisions and drinks for re-sale. She says thanks to all who make this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and drinks for re-sale

loans.name: Eva Emil's Nguvu Mpya Group

texts.en:
Eva E., age 46, is married with 6 children (ages 24, 22, 18,15, 9, and 6). For the past 4 years, she has had a café, where she sells food and drinks. She works from 6 AM to 6 PM daily, and earns about $60 profit a month.

Eva has had two previous loans from Tujijenge Tanzania, which she used to increase her business. She plans to use the new loan to buy a blender and make more juice so she can increase sales. Eva will share this loan with her loan group Nguvu Mpya, which has 16 members. These members will hold each other accountable to pay back their loans.

In the picture, Eva is second from the right, in the middle row.

loans.use: Purchase a blender to increase juice/beverage production and sales

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Tujijenge Tanzania Ltd - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Juhudi Group

texts.en:
Costancia has been selling chickens in Arusha for eight years. She is 35 years old, married, and has nine-year-old twins. She works daily from 6:00am to 6:00pm selling chickens and is able to earn approximately $400 in profit each month.

Costancia would like to take out this loan to buy more chickens to sell. Increasing her inventory of poultry will increase her profits. She will be sharing this loan with her two group members, one of whom owns a stationary shop while the other sells vegetables.

loans.use: To buy more chickens to sell in her business.

loans.name: Joy

texts.en: Joy S. is 25 years old and married with 2 children. She lives in Benin City with her family. Joy learnt this business for 6 months. She started her own business in 2005. Joy needs the loan amount of US$ 525 to buy more provisions for re-sale. She is grateful to all who make the loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more provisions for re-sale

loans.name: Veronica Kasaba's Busara Group

texts.en:
Veronica K., age 32, is married and has a 9-year-old son. She has a poultry business that she started 5 years ago. She works from 6 AM to 8 AM daily and she earns a monthly profit of about $185.

In the past, Veronica took 2 loans from Tujijenge Tanzania to increase her business. She requests a new loan to increase her capital. Veronica plans to share this loan with her loan group, Busara, which has 20 members. These members hold each other accountable for paying back their loans.

In the picture, Veronica is the first person on the left in the back row, in a pink blouse.

loans.use: Increase capital in order to generate greater profit

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Tujijenge Tanzania Ltd - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Manong

texts.en:
Manong M. lives in Tanzania. He has a shop where he sells a variety of food, including maize flour, beans, rice, and sugar. He purchases the items wholesale from shops around and outside the Dar-es-Salaam city center.

Manong's shop provides enough income to feed his family and pay the school fees for his three children. He requests a loan of $400 to purchase more items to sell and increase his business.

loans.use: Purchase more food to sell

loans.name: Shani

texts.en:
Shani is 25 years old, married, and has 2 children, ages 6 and 1. She has owned a small food vending store since 2004. She works from 8am to 6pm at her business everyday and can earn a monthly profit of about $90 from her sales.

Shani now hopes for a loan to buy more food items such as rice, maize flour, meat, vegetables, and bananas for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items to increase her inventory.

loans.name: Fatuma's Mamboleo Group

texts.en:
Fatuma is 40 years old, married, and has 3 children, ages 26, 24, and 22. She has been selling clothes since 2000. She works from 8am to 7pm at her business everyday and can earn a monthly profit of about $150 from her sales.

Fatuma now hopes for a loan to buy more clothes for her business. She will also share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses in fish, clothing, and potato sales.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to increase her inventory.

loans.name: Merry

texts.en: Merry has been selling milk in Arusha for six years.  She is 27 years old, married, and has three children, ages 5, 8, and 12 years old.  She works daily from 8:00am to 4:00pm and is able to earn a monthly profit of approximately $60.  Merry is hoping to take out a loan in order to give her more capital to expand her business.  With more materials, she expects to be able to increase her profit.

loans.use: To buy more materials to increase her sales of milk.

loans.name: Asia's Tujuane Group

texts.en:

Asia now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members Sikudhan, Vaileth, Lenarda, Salome, and Nuru, who also own businesses.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

Anna hopes this loan can go towards buying more charcoal for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who also have businesses selling clothing and food.

loans.name: Jacquiline

loans.use: To buy more materials to tailor clothing.

loans.name: Mwanahamis's Heshima Group

Mwanahamis now hopes for a loan to buy more food items such as rice, maize flour, vegetables, and bananas for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup members, who have businesses in clothing sales and own their own shop.

loans.use: To buy more items to increase her stock.

loans.name: Moshi

texts.en:
Moshi is a married woman with 3 children aged 25, 21 and 14. She own a small food vendor store since in 1880. Every day, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $65 from her sales.

Moshi now hopes for a loan to buy more rice, maize flour, meat, vegetables and bananas for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

loans.name: Neema

texts.en:
Neema R. is a married, Tanzanian woman. She runs a tailoring shop in the Vituka area outside the Dar-es Salaam city center. She makes a variety of clothes in different sizes for women, men, and children, including school uniforms. She purchases the materials from the Karia Koo shopping center in Dar-es-Salaam.

Neema has been running this business for two years. Her life depends on this business. She requests a loan of $550 to purchase more materials so she can expand her business.

loans.use: Purchase more materials to make more clothese to sell

loans.name: Moshi

texts.en:
Moshi is a married woman with 3 children ages between 25 and 14. She own a small food vendor store since in 1880. Every day, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $65 from her sales.

Moshi now hopes for a loan to buy more rice, maize flour, meat, vegetables and bananas for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business.

Sera will share this loan with her group member, Dena, who owns a business in Arusha selling clothing.

loans.use: To buy more materials to expand her business.

loans.name: Fatuma H Mamboleo Group

Fatuma is 40 years old, married, and has 3 children, ages 10, 5, and 3. She became a clothing seller in 1999. She works from 7am to 6pm at her business everyday and can earn a monthly profit of about $70 from her sales.

Fatuma hopes her new loan can help her buy more clothes for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Tatu, who is also in the business of clothing sales.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for her business.

loans.name: Elice's Group
