Faustina D. is a fishmonger.  She is married, but her husband's income as a carpenter is not sufficient for Faustina and her child. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Christian Rural Aid Network (CRAN) - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Godfrey

texts.en: Godfrey E. is 35 years old and single.  He lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria.  He runs a cold room where he sells frozen fish. He has been in this business since 2002.  He needs the loan amount of $275 to buy more fish to sell from his cold room.

loans.use: To buy more fish to sell

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Keang

texts.en:
Mrs. Keang T., 40, was married to her husband in 2004. She has three daughters from a previous marriage. All of her daughters have full-time employment in Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Keang has been selling Khmer cakes (sticky rice sweet cakes) since 2005. She buys them at the market for resale in front of her house. Her husband works as a driver. The main income for the family is from her daughters' salaries. They each travel to work by motor taxi, and so Keang is requesting a loan of 1200 USD to purchase a motorcycle for her daughters to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her daughters to drive to work

loans.name: Mabel

texts.en: Mabel I. is 49 years old and married with 3 children.  She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria.  She sells provisions, drinks, and foodstuffs.  She has been in this business since 2003.  She needs the loan amount of $450 to buy more drinks, provisions, and foodstuffs to sell.

loans.use: To buy more drinks, provisions, and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria I. is 45 years old and married with 4 children.  She sells provisions and foodstuffs.  She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria.  She has been in this business since 2000.  She needs the loan amount of $450 to buy more foodstuffs and provisions to sell.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr:
Fatou S. is a young unmarried woman who did not have the opportunity for normal schooling. She isn’t giving up and rejects idleness by working in the commerce of oranges and other goods. She is requesting this loan to boost her business, given that the month of Ramadan is looming on the horizon. It will be a time of high demand for fruit and various other goods.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Fatou S. est une jeune célibataire qui n'a pas eu la chance de mener ses études normalement. Elle ne désarme pas et refuse l'oisivité en menant des activités de commerce d'oranges et autres produits. Elle sollicite ce prêt pour renforcer son commerce avec le mois de Ramadan qui se profile à l'horizonet qui sera une période de forte demande en fruits et autres produits divers.

loans.use: Commerce

loans.name: Mrs. Gai Group

texts.vi:
Mrs. N. Thi Gai (DOB: 20/09/1961, ID: 23010087) would like to borrow a loan of 4.028.000 VND to invest in breeding ducks. Currently, about 300 ducks are being bred for eggs in her home. Another daily source of income is from her small business in the market. Mrs. Gai’s husband is a construction worker. She has three children, all of whom are still in school. Her family’s monthly income is about 3.000.000 VND. Other members in her group include:

-Mrs. D. Thi Ha (born in 1980, ID: 23010085) would like to borrow a loan of 4.028.000 VND to invest in her business in the market.

-Mrs. L. Thi Thuan (born in 1974, ID: 23010075) would like to borrow a loan of 4.452.000 VND to invest in poultries.

-Mrs. H. Thi Chung (born in 1974, ID: 23010071) would like to borrow a loan of 4.028.000 VND to improve the infrastructure.

-Mrs. V. Thi Hai (born in 1960, ID: 23010140) would like to borrow a loan of 4.028.000 VND to invest in poultries.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khoa N., Kiva Volunteer.

Nguyễn Thị Gái, sinh ngày 20/09/1961 (Ms 23010087), mức vay: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi vịt. Gia đình cô đang nuôi khoảng 300 con vịt đẻ. Ngoài việc nuôi vịt đẻ, cô còn đi chợ buôn bán nhỏ có thu nhập theo ngày . Hàng ngày, chồng cô cùng những người trong làng đi phu hồ tại các công trình, 3 con cô đang độ tuổi đi học. Thu nhập bình quân của gia đình khoảng: 3.000.000 vnđ / tháng. Trong nhóm cô còn có: Đào Thị Hà, sinh năm 1980 (Ms 23010085 ), mức vay:4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư đi chợ. Lê Thị Thuận, sinh năm 1974 (Ms 23010075 ), mức vay: 4.452.000 vnđ để đầu tư chăn nuôi. Hoàng Thị Chung, sinh năm 1974 (Ms 23010071 ), mức vay: 4.028.000 vnđ để đầu tư cơ sở hạ tầng. Vũ Thị Hải, sinh năm 1960 (Ms 23010140), mức vay: 4.028.000 vnđ để chăn nuôi.

loans.use: chăn nuôi

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en: Lydia I. is forty-two years old.  She is married with six children.  She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria.  She sells foodstuffs and kerosene to people in her community.  This is a business she has been in since 1997.  She is a LAPO (Kiva’s Field Partner) client.  She needs the loan of $450 to buy more foodstuffs to sell.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Imade

texts.en: Imade T. is 40 years old and married with three children.  She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria.  She owns a restaurant where she sells cooked food to people in her community.  She has been in this business since 1998.  She needs the loan amount of $275 to buy more drinks to supplement her sale of cooked food and thereby serve her customers better.

loans.use: To buy more drinks to sell at her restaurant

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Assane Guisse

texts.fr:
Assane is an experience tailor. He is married and lives in the working-class district of Belfort. He is requesting a loan of 300,000 francs CFA in order to prepare for Korité (the holiday that follows the fasting of Ramadan) by buying a major stock of boutique items and fabrics.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Assane est un tailleur expérimenté. Il est marié et vit au populaire quartier de Belfort. Il sollicite un prêt de 300 000 F CFA afin de préparer la fête de la Korité en achetant un important stock de mercerie et de tissus.

loans.use: To sew clothing

loans.name: Lot

texts.en:
Mr. Lot M., 41, and his wife, Mrs. Ry Sim, 34, live in a small village off of National Road #2 south of Phnom Penh. They were married in 1990 and have six children: one son and five daughters. Three of their children are in school and one daughter is a garment factory worker.

Mrs. Lot has been a motor taxi driver for eighteen years. He carries people from his village to Phnom Penh City. His wife has been selling Khmer noodle and gruel in the village for over one year. Lot's motorcycle is broken and he needs to install a new one but he lacks the money for buying it. So, he is requesting a loan of 600 USD to purchase a new motorcycle for his business.

loans.use: To purchase a new motorcycle

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en: Aisha M. is 42 years old and married with 6 children.  She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria.  She is in the business of selling foodstuffs like melon, pepper, and palm oil.  She sells in the local market in her area.  She has been in this business since 2004.  She needs the loan amount of $450 to buy more bags of rice and beans to sell.  She says the loan will enable her to make more profit.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice and bags of beans to sell

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Sophoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophoeun C., 39, and her husband, Mr. Thorn Pean, 39, who live in a small village across the Mekong River, were married in 1983 and have four children, one son and three daughters. One of their daughters is married and lives outside the family home. Their son has full-time employment in Phnom Penh. One daughter is a silk weaver and the other daughter is in school. Mr. Thorn has been a mason for twenty-five years.

Mrs. Sophoeun has been a silk weaver for fourteen years, a skill she learned from her neighbor. She sells her finished products to a reseller in the village, who takes it to sell in Phnom Penh. Sophoeun is requesting a loan of 500 USD to purchase silk materials for her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving

loans.name: Somaly

texts.en:
Mrs. Somaly I., 46, is widow with three children: one son and two daughters. The son is married and lives outside the family home while her two daughters are garment factory workers. The family lives along National Road #5 about eighteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Somaly has been in the business of selling grocery items since 1993. She bought them from market for resale in the village. She is in the process of building her house and lacks the funds to finish I.. She is requesting a loan of $500 to buy pillars and construct the final walls of her house.

loans.use: To provide for the completion of her house

loans.name: Polycarp

texts.en: Polycarp A. is 40 years old and married and has 2 children.  Polycarp lives in Ekperi, Edo State, Nigeria.  He owns a piece of land where he plants groundnuts and corn.  He started farming in 1998.  He is in need of the loan amount of $850 to buy fertilizers and hire labourers to clear his farmland.

loans.use: To buy more fertilizer and hire labor for clearing my farm

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Joel

texts.en: Joel I. is thirty-two years old and married with three children.  He lives in Uromi, Edo State, Nigeria.  He sells various types of bricks for building houses.  He has been in this business for the past five years.  Joel finished repayment of his last loan.  He needs the loan amount of $1025 to buy more materials for making bricks to sell.

loans.use: To buy materials for moldings bricks to sell

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Thou

texts.en:
Mrs. Thou S., 63, and her husband were married in 1979. They have seven children: four sons and three daughters. Two of their children are married and live outside the family home. Of the other five children, one of them works in the village hospital, one is a silk weaver at home, and the other three are in the local school. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River near Phnom Penh.

Mrs. Thou has been a silk weaver since she was fifteen years old, a skill she learned from her mother. Her husband is retired now. She is requesting a loan of 300 USD to purchase silk materials to continue her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en: Felicia O. says that selling provisions and body cream is a lucrative business.  She is thirty-two years old and married with four children.  She lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria.  She has been in this business of selling provisions and body cream for the past four years.  She needs the loan amount of $700 to buy more inventory to sell.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and body cream to sell

loans.name: Laiheak

texts.en:
Mrs. Laiheak C., 36, and her husband, Mr. Sam-at Horn, 41, live on an island in the Mekong River near Phnom Penh, were married in 1991 and have four children, three sons and one daughter. Three of their children are in the local school.

Mrs. Laiheak has been a silk weaver for fifteen years, a skill she learned from her neighbor. She sells her finished products to a reseller nearby, who then takes it to sell in Phnom Penh. Mr. Sam-at was a silk weaver himself but has recently gone into carpentry. Laiheak is requesting a loan of 200 USD to purchase materials to construct a roof and walls of her house.

loans.use: To purchase materials to complete her house

loans.name: Hakly

texts.en:
Mr. Hakly S., 41, and his wife, Mrs. Hoy Chhaum, 41, live on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1987 and have six children, one son and five daughters. One of their daughters is a garment factory worker and another is studying at a local school.

Mr. Hakly has been a cook for ten years, a skill he learned from his neighbor. He cooks for wedding parties and other ceremonies in his nearby villages, while Mrs. Hoy stays at home to take care of the children. Hakly is in the process of repairing his house but lacks the money to buy zinc to roof his house. Therefore, he is requesting a loan of 150 USD to purchase materials to roof his house.

loans.use: To purchase material to roof his house

loans.name: Agnes Margaret

texts.en: Agnes Margaret E. is 35 years old and married with seven children.  She lives in Uromi, Edo State, Nigeria.  She owns a bar where she sells various brands of drinks.  She has been in this business since 2000.  She needs the loan amount of $700 to buy more drinks and purified water to sell.  She says thank you to Kiva lenders and LAPO (Kiva’s Field Partner).

loans.use: To buy more drinks and purified water to sell

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Christiana Okuduwa is 65 years old and is married with eight children.  She lives in Okpella, in the Edo state of Nigeria.  Christiana runs a business selling drinks and other provisions to people in her community, but she also sells some of her products in the main village market.  She has been in this business since 1999, but now needs a loan of $700 to achieve her goal of buying goods wholesale and reselling them to the people in her community.

loans.use: To buy more drinks and provisions for sale.

loans.name: Ayesha's Group

texts.en:
Ayesha baji is a widow of M. A. and has been living in a city named Arifwala, Pakistan for the last 29 years. Ayesha baji owns a three-room house. She is the mother of one son, Nadeem Akhtar. He is 21 years old and he has been in the business of selling cosmetics for the last 4 years. Ayesha baji successfully completed her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is requesting a loan to buy more cosmetics to sell retail.

She is joined in her loan group by a three other members. Rani baji, Rashida baji, Zainab baji, and Zainab baji. Rani, Rashida, and Zainab request loans to buy fruits wholesale to sell retail. Zareena baji requests a loan to repair an auto-rickshaw (local three-wheel vehicle).

The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To improve current businesses

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort E. is 37 years old and is married with two children.  She lives in Okpella, in the Edo state of Nigeria.  Comfort has owned a restaurant which sells a wide variety of foodstuffs to customers for over 13 years.  Her restaurant has gained in popularity over these years, and now she needs a loan of $700 to purchase more foodstuffs to meet the demands of the customers in her community.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for cooking.

loans.name: Yelena

texts.en:
Yelena is divorced and lives with her grown daughter and a mentally-ill aunt, whom she cares for. She runs her small clothing business in the central city market of Simferopol. Yelena sells casual and party outfits for women. She has been in this business for four years. Her hard work and personal determination give Yelena a strong and stable position among her competitors. Presently, she has over $5,000 invested in her business. Her monthly income is about $1,200.  

Yelena is requesting a loan of 3000 Grivnas to purchase additional merchandise. She is a focused entrepreneur willing to work longer hours even after all her competitors are already done for the day. Yelena treats all her customers with respect and takes time to show them the assorted merchandise she offers for sale in her store. She works hard to keep her business running and hopes to generate additional income to buy some electric appliances and new furniture for her house.

Note: this is a short-term, "seasonal" loan that will be repaid in a month.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise

loans.name: Farhat's Group

texts.en:
Farhat baji is a wife of M. T. and lives in a city named Arifwala, Pakistan. She owns a three-room brick house. She is the mother of two children: one daughter and one son. Her son runs a grocery shop. Her daughter is in 8th standard. Her husband is a milk seller and has been in this profession for the last 12 years. In Pakistan, milk is typically sold door-to-door each day. Farhat baji is a housewife and prefers to stay home and do housework. Farhat baji successfully completed two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is requesting a loan to buy more materials (rice, lentils) for her son's grocery shop and to buy more milk for her husband's business.

She is joined in her loan group by: Sardaran baji, Shahnaz baji and Ruqaiya baji who are requesting loans to buy more fruits for their fruit businesses; and Bilquis baji who requests a loan to buy more materials for her grocery shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Olga

texts.en:
Olga is single. She lives in Simferopol, Crimea, with her mother and sister. Olga launched her enterprise 12 years ago with the assistance of her partner. Today she is still selling women's clothing in the central market of her city. She charges only 50% extra on each piece of clothing, which has become one of the best attractions in her business. Olga has about $2,000 invested in merchandise, and her net profit is about $400 each month. Her affordable pricing policy causes good turnover of her inventory and brings Olga high profits. 

Olga is seeking a 2000 Grivna ($450) loan to increase her turnover and sales rates. Olga started this business when she couldn't find any other way to support herself and her family, so this venture is just like her baby, and she is very excited to see it expand and become sustainable. Olga is hoping to make good money in business and eventually do some repairs to her family's house.

loans.use: To increase her stock and turnover

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca O. is 42 years old and is married with four children.  She has been managing a business in Jattu, in the Edo state of Nigeria, since 1991 and has been successful in expanding the shoe sales from her store.  Now Rebecca needs a loan of $700 to expand her business by purchasing more shoes.

loans.use: To buy more shoes for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase additional inventory

loans.name: Rukhsana's Group

texts.en:
Rukhsana baji is a wife of M. F. and has been living in a city named Arifwala, Pakistan. Rukhsana baji got education up to the 8th standard. She owns a two-room brick house. She is the mother of two daughters. Both are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Rukhsana baji is a housewife and prefers to do domestic work and take care of her daughters. Her husband is a fruit seller and has been in this profession for the last 8 years. Rukhsana baji successfully completed her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is requesting a loan to buy more fruits for her husband's business.

She is joined in her loan group by 4 other members. Chaman baji requests a loan to buy cosmetics to resell. Shahnaz baji requests a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (local three-wheel vehicle). Asma baji requests a loan to buy fruits to resell. Shamim baji requests a loan to buy more materials for her grocery shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Hosanna Trust Group

texts.en: Elizabeth is 41 years old and is married with four kids (located in the front row of the picture in yellow). Elizabeth is the leader of a six member trust group called the Hosanna Trust Group. They all trade in food items such as, rice, plantain, vegetable oil, dried fish, palm oil, vegetables, charcoal, and more. They work really hard to support their households.  However, the best they do is not enough to make a meaningful impact because they are constrained by funds to grow these businesses. They are convinced that the loan facility will turn the situational wheel around to give hope and future for their businesses and families. Members in this group agree to guarantee for one another as social collateral and provide support and assistance to help repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy assorted food commodities like  rice, beans, yams, vegetables, vegetable oil, meat etc.

loans.name: Arzi-Gul'

texts.en:
Arzi-Gul' is married with two grown sons. She sells women's clothing in a local marketplace called Moskoltso, in Simferopol. Her kiosk is well-known for reasonable prices, friendly customer service and high-quality stock. Arzi-Gul' has been in this venture for 3 years and had some experience working in Hungary. Presently, she has over $40,000 invested in inventory. 

Arzi-Gul' is requesting a loan of 4000 Grivnas ($875) to purchase additional stock for a new vending location. Assorted merchandise will help Arzi-Gul' increase her sales and income as a result. Her previous experience working as a trade expert, combined with high demand on this type of product, secure stable growth of Arzi-Gul's business and further success of her venture. One of her long-term plans is opening new vending locations in the same marketplace. Arzi-Gul' is hoping to generate enough income to do some repairs to her house sometime in the future.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock

loans.name: Amiran's Group

texts.en:
Amiran baji is a wife of M. Y. and lives in a city named Arifwala, Pakistan. Amiran baji couldn't get an education due to poor financial conditions. She owns a two-room house and has been living in it for the last 10 years. She is the mother of four children: three sons and one daughter. Her elder sons make decoratively embroidered clothes. Her younger son and daughter are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Amiran baji is a housewife. Her husband sells popcorn and has been in this profession for the last 12 years. Amiran baji successfully completed her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan to buy another popcorn machine to expand her husband's business.

She is joined in her loan group by a few more members. Waziran baji requests a loan to buy cloth for her garment business. Naziran baji and Rushda baji each are requesting a loan to buy more fruits to sell. Shamim baji requests a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheel vehicle).

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand and improve each group member's business

loans.name: Umuru

texts.en: Umuru A. is 33 years old and married with one child.  He lives in Jattu, in the Edo state of Nigeria, and is in the business of selling bags of garri, which is a product of cassava that has been ground and fried.  Umuru sells the bags of garri at the local market in his community for a profit, and has also been a long-time secretary of the microfinance lending group in his area.  In order to expand his business, Umuru is requesting a loan of $1,025 to purchase more bags of garri for resale.

loans.use: To buy more bags of garri for sale.

loans.name: Hanifan's Group

texts.en:
Hanifan baji is a wife of M. A. and lives in a city named Arifwala, Pakistan. Hanifan baji owns a two-room house and has been living in it for the last 23 years. She is the mother of three children: two sons and one daughter. All of her children are enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Her husband has a mobile phone business. He has been in this profession for the last 6 years. Hanifan baji is a housewife and prefers to do domestic work. She successfully completed her two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is requesting a loan to buy more mobile phones to expand her husband's business.

She is joined in her loan group by 5 other members. Shamim baji requests a loan to buy wheat and corn to resell. Razia baji requests a loan to buy more fruits for her fruit business. Arshan baji requests a loan to buy more materials for her grocery shop. Saima baji requests a loan to buy cosmetics to resell. Shamim baji requests a loan to repair her auto-rickshaw.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses

loans.name: Faith

texts.en: Faith O. is 36 years old and married without children.  She lives in Benin City, in the Edo state of Nigeria.  Since 2005, she has been selling clothing materials and offering sewing services.  In order to expand her business, Faith is requesting a loan of $450, which will be used to purchase more tailoring materials.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring materials for cloth production.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria O. is 41 years old and is married with six children.  She lives in Benin City, in the Edo state of Nigeria.  Maria has been in the business of soap production for over six years, and is now a successful producer and distributor of soaps in her community.  In order to further expand her business and attract more customers, Maria needs a loan of $1,200, which will be used to purchase key ingredients for making soap.

loans.use: To buy more materials for making soap.

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en: Rosemary S. is 51 years old and is married with six children.  She lives in Benin City, in the Edo state of Nigeria, and is in the business of bead making and selling phone cards.  Rosemary has worked in this sector since 2002, and has expanded her bead business by selling to people in schools and markets.  In order to purchase more bead manufacturing materials and tools, she now requires a loan of $1,200.

loans.use: To buy materials for my bead making.

loans.name: Efosa

texts.en: Efosa A. is 36 years old and is married with one child.  He lives in Benin City, in the Edo state of Nigeria.  Having been trained as a motor mechanic, he works in Benin City and sells motor spare parts to people in his community.  In order to further expand his business and attract his customers, Efosa needs a loan of $1,025 to purchase more spare parts and attain further skills.

loans.use: To buy more spare parts for sales.

loans.name: Josephine's Maelewano Group

texts.en:
Josephine is 27 years,She is a single woman. Take care of 2 people aged 65 and 55 years old. She own a small salon. Every day, she works from 8am to 7.30pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $500 from her sales.

Josephine now hopes for a loan to buy more salon items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Merry, who also has business dealing with food vending.

loans.use: To buy more salon item to increase her stock

loans.name: Ester's Maelewano Group

texts.en:
Ester is 40. She is married and has a 10-year-old child. She also provides for two other people, 21 and 26 years of age. She has owned a small shop since 2004. Every day, she works from 6 am to 10 pm and earns about $140 each month.

Ester is aksing for a loan to buy salt, sugar, rice, and oil for resale. She will share this loan with her group members, who retail food and run small cafes.

loans.use: To increase inventory in her grocery.

loans.name: Ofure

texts.en: Ofure O. is 41 years old and married with 4 children. He lives in Benin City, Edo state. Nigeria. He learnt this business for seven months and has been into this business since 1998. He needs the loan amount of $600 to buy more oil and lubricant for sales .

loans.use:
To buy more oil and lubricant for sales 

To buy more oil and lubricant for sales

loans.name: Ruth's Warumi Group

texts.en:
Ruth is married and has 2 children, 9 and 15 years of age. She is also the caregiver for another three people, 45, 48, and 60 years of age. She has owned a small shop since 2003. Every day, she works from 7.30 am to 12.45 pm and earns about $110 each month.

Ruth is aksing for a loan to increase her inventory. She will share this loan with her group members. One is a grocer, another is a florist, and the third sells clothing.

loans.use: To increase stock in a small store.

loans.name: Neema

texts.en:
Neema is married and has 2 children, 21 and 23 years of age. She is also the caregiver for another person, who is 40 years of age. Neema started a business selling clothes in 2007. Every day, she works from 7 am to 12 pm and earns about $50 each month.

Neema is aksing for a loan to increase her clothing inventory.

loans.use: To buy clothes for resale.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a business woman in Tema.  She is married and blessed with two kids who are currently in school. She sells Dumas clothes and ice cream. Mary is very supportive to her family through her trading business. She has been selling for the past eight years, but progress has been persistently low due to insufficient funds. She hopes the loan will enable her to revive the business and make it more viable. She wants to purchase a bulk of Dumas clothes and also increase the production of ice cream. She belongs to the group called the Platinum Trust Group. The group provides assistance and support for one another to repay the loan.

loans.use: To purchase bulk of Dumas clothes and raw materials for ice cream.

loans.name: Gifty

texts.en: Gifty is a 24-year-old business woman and is married with two children. Her two kids are currently in school. She has been a seamstress for seven years. She sews many types of female clothing including kaba and slit, wedding dresses, funeral clothes, and much more. She also sells women's jeans, skirts, tops and other clothing. She wants to use the loan to buy increased supplies of sewing materials like linen, threads, thimbles, etc. to increase her output and efficiency. She hopes to double her savings to provide her children with a quality education. She is a member of the community group Platinum Group. In this group, members guarantee one another as social collateral to access and repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy increased supplies of sewing material like linen, threads, thimbles, etc.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sinapi Aba Trust (SAT) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Leddy's Amkeni Group

texts.en:
Leddy is 27. She is married and has 3 children between the ages of 8 and 12. She opened a tailoring shop in 2003. Every day, she works from 7 am to 5.30 pm and earns about $25 each month.

Leddy is asking for a loan to buy inventory for her tailoring business. She will share this loan with her group members, who run businesses selling soap.

loans.use: To buy inventory for her tailoring shop.

loans.name: Onesta's Amkeni Group

texts.en:
Onesta is 36. She is single and has 2 children, 15 and 9. She started her business in 1994. Every day, she works from 7 am to 6pm and earns about $25 a month.

Onesta is aksing for a loan to buy more fish. She will share this loan with her group members, who sell clothes and food.

loans.use: To buy fish

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Gloria is 38 years old and is a wife and mother of two kids who are currently in school. She has been sewing for eight years and specializes in female clothing. Her skills and designs are very classy. She sews various kinds of styles that give her customers new looks, including kaba and slit, wedding dresses, funeral clothes, etc. Gloria also sells maize  for extra income to support her family. She will use the loan to buy increased supplies of sewing materials like linen, threads, thimbles, etc. and also more maize to increase her output and efficiency. She hopes to increase her savings to provide her children with a quality education. She is a member of the community group Platinum Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access and repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy increased supplies of sewing material like linen, threads, thimbles, etc. as well as maize.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sinapi Aba Trust (SAT) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Hiyana's Amkeni Group

texts.en:
Hiyana is 39. She is a married and has three children, 23, 16, and 6 years of age. She opened a food market in 1986. Every day, she works from 10 am to 10 pm and earns about $25 each month.

Hiyana is asking for a loan to buy rice, maize, flour, meat, vegetables, and bananas. She will share this loan with her group members, who sell soap and groceries.

loans.use: To buy inventory for her grocery store.

loans.name: Monica's Motomoto Group

texts.en:
Monica is 24. She is a married and has a two-year-old child.. Since 2003, she has run a pool parlor a bicycle-rental business. She works every day from 10 am to 10:40 pm and earns about $25 each month.

Monica is asking for a loan to buy more bicycles. She will share this loan with her group, Happiness..

loans.use: To buy bicycles

loans.name: Toyin

texts.en: Toyin O. is 40 years old and married with three children.  She currently manages a business that produces and sells bricks to customers, but she also has a shop where she sells general building supplies.  Because Toyin gives financially unstable customers a one-month grace period, she has been able to attract many customers over the years.  She employs several young men who are paid on a daily basis and help her produce bricks.  Toyin now needs a loan of $700 which will help her purchase more materials for making bricks.

loans.use: To purchase materials for brick-making.

loans.name: Ekatte

texts.en: Ekatte "Mama" Uche is a retired teacher, who is married and has five older children.  She sells lubricant in wholesale and retail quantities in Lagos, Nigeria, and has managed her own business since 2002.  Mama Uche also supplies eggs to local retailers, which provides her with an even greater income.  In order to expand her business and increase her inventory, Mama Uche is requesting a loan of $850.

loans.use: To purchase more lubricant.

loans.name: Felista's Muungano Group

texts.en:
Felista is 30 years old. She is a married woman with 1 child aged 10. She has owned and run a small pharmacy since 2005. She works everyday from 6.30am to 9pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

Felista requests a loan to buy more medicine and medical items for her business. She will share this loan with her subgroup member Fatuma, who has a business selling charcoal.

loans.use: To increase her inventory.

loans.name: Ekundayo

texts.en: Ekundayo H. is 30 years and married with four children.  She lives in Lagos, Nigeria, and is motivated to see her children through school; currently, her eldest child is in primary school.  Since she was four years old, Ekundayo has been sewing clothes and since 1998, she has created and sold traditional Nigerian designs.    She also sells tailoring materials like zippers, threads, and landings.  Ekundayo hopes for a loan of $525, which will help her purchase more tailoring materials for resale.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is 23 years old and is single. She became a clothes seller in 2006. She works everyday from 7am to 12pm and can earn a monthly profit of about $175 from her sales.

Mariam requests a loan to buy more clothes for her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to increase her stock.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence A. is 46 years and married with six children.  She lives in Lagos, in Nigeria, and owns a business which sells and distributes kerosene and medicinal drugs.  Florence has been working in this area since 2004, and has also been the leader of a microfinance lending group.  In order to meet increased customer demand, Florence needs a loan of $850, which will be used to purchase more kerosene fuel and medicines.

loans.use: To purchase kerosene and medicine for resale.

loans.name: Adeola

texts.en: Adeola F. is 41 years old, and is married with four children.  She works as the secretary of a microfinance lending group in Lagos, Nigeria, but is also a hair stylist and salesperson for all kinds of household slippers.  Adeola has been in the hairstyling business since 1995, and is now facing increasing demands from customers.  In order to purchase more hair extension tools and slippers, she is requesting a loan of $525.

loans.use: To purchase more slippers and hair extensions.

loans.name: Martina

texts.en:
Martina is 46 years old. She is a single woman with 3 children aged 18, 15 and 11 and also takes care of 1 other child aged 11. She became a alcohol seller in 1988. She works everyday from 4pm to 11pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $40 from her sales.

Martina requests a loan to buy more alcohol products for her business.

loans.use: To increase her inventory.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en: Lydia A. is 48 years old, and is married with three children.  She lives in the town of Ikotun, near Lagos, in Nigeria.  She currently runs a business selling kerosene in wholesale quantities, and has been doing this since 2004, when she taught herself about the kerosene business.  In order to purchase another tank for storing kerosene, Lydia is requesting a loan of $600.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosene for sale.

loans.name: Modupe

texts.en: Modupe "Mama" O. is 57 years old and married with six children in Lagos, Nigeria.  She is the leader of a microfinance lending group, and runs a business selling fufu from yams and cassava.  Mama makes fufu from the yams and cassava by drying the vegetables in the sun, grinding them to powder, and then boiling the powder until it is hard and smooth.  Mama learned this trade from friends of her mother many years ago, and has been selling this food staple for much of her life.  In order to keep up with customer demand, Mama now needs a loan of $600 to purchase more yams and cassava.

loans.use: To purchase more ingredients for food production.

loans.name: Nike

texts.en: Nike A. is 47 years old and married with two children.  For many years, she has managed a business in Lagos, Nigeria, that rents out chairs, pots, and coolers for social gatherings.  Nike's business also decorates halls and caters some of these occasions.  In order to expand her business, she requires a loan of $700, which will allow her to purchase more goods to rent to customers.

loans.use: To purchase more rentable goods.

loans.name: Folashade

texts.en: Folashade O. owns a restaurant is 48 years old and is married with three children, all of whom are in secondary school and are currently preparing to attend higher institutions of education.  For many years she has owned a restaurant in Lagos, Nigeria, where she sells drinks, food, and pepper soups.  During the day, she sells food, while at night customers order mostly pepper soup and drinks.  Folashade has several assistants who help attend to customers, and is now requesting a loan of $600 to purchase more ingredients and drinks.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks and soup ingredients.

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en: Rosemary A. is 40 years old and is married with three children.  She sells fruit drinks wholesale and retail in Lagos, Nigeria, where she also sells foodstuffs like semovita, rice, and beans.  She has managed this business for three years, but is now finding that she lacks the funds necessary to keep up with demand from customers.  Therefore, she is requesting a loan of $600 to buy more foodstuffs and fruit drinks.  Her long term goal is to help put her children through school so that she can be referred to as "Mama Graduates."

loans.use: To purchase more fruit drinks and foodstuffs.

loans.name: Assaad

texts.en:
Assaad is 66 years old, married, and the father of one child. He lives with his family in a village close to Saida, south of Lebanon.

Assaad runs two parallel businesses: he owns a small shop selling gadgets and accessories and is also a taxi driver. He has been a microcredit client of Al Majmoua for the past three years. According to Assaad, the loans he requested were very supportive and resulted in a lot of positive changes in his life. He was able to help his child receive a good education and was also able purchase a taxi car that increased his income and guaranteed a better livelihood for his family. This time, Assaad needs a loan for $1200 to conduct maintenance on his taxi car.

loans.use: Conduct maintenance on his taxi car

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth J. is married with three children.  She is 37 years old and lives in Lagos, Nigeria, with her family.  She owns and runs a restaurant where she sells drinks and variety of pepper soups, like goat, fish, chicken and beef.  Elizabeth has been in this business since 2006.  During the day she sells food and drinks but in the evenings she sells only drinks and pepper soup until midnight. Elizabeth has several  girls who assist her with running the business. Elizabeth now needs a loan of $600 to purchase drink crates and soup ingredients.

loans.use: To purchase drink crates and ingredients.

loans.name: Iyabode

texts.en: Iyabode is 40 years old and has 2 children.  She is married and lives in Lagos State with her family.  Iyabode sells children's clothes and adult underwear. She has been in this business for a long time.  She sells in wholesale and retail to her customers.  With the constant increase in demand for her goods, she needs an additional loan of $850 to buy more children’s clothes and adult underwear. She is grateful to Kiva lenders and LAPO Microfinance (Kiva’s Field Partner) for their financial support and business training.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and underwear to sell

loans.name: Angela

texts.en: Angela has a shop where she sells bags of cement and mould blocks.  She has sale boys who work for her and are paid on a daily basis.  Angela is a LAPO client, and she has been in this business for the past five years.  Angela is 38 years old and married with 3 children.  Angela needs the loan amount of $600 to buy materials for making blocks.  She expresses her gratitude to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To purchase bags of cement and materials for block making

loans.name: Bilal

texts.en:
BilA. is 28 years old, single, and lives in a small village close to Saida, South of Lebanon. He owns a cellphone shop and is the only person who also has a satellite station in the area where he lives. He started his business thanks to loans he requested from A. Majmoua in the past, which he successfully repaid on-time.

BilA. has been a microcredit client of A. Majmoua for the past three years. Presently, he needs a loan for $1200 to open an internet cafe. Indeed, there's a big need for such service in his area.

loans.use: To open an internet cafe

loans.name: Adenike

texts.en:
Adenike is 39 years old and married with three children. She sells drugs and produces liquid soap. She supplies the liquid soap to supermarkets to sell. She needs the loan amount of $700 to buy more drugs and materials for making liquid soap.

Adenike started her business in 2002. This loan will go a long way in helping her business grow. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To increase her stock of drugs and purchase materials for making liquid soap

loans.name: Abimbola

texts.en: Abimbola T. is 35 years old and married with two children.  She learned this trade for two years before setting up her own business in 1993.  Abimbola sells soft drinks, and she is also a hair stylist.  She needs the loan amount of $600 to buy more materials like hair oil, relaxer, hair extensions, and weaves for hair styling.  Abimbola said this will prevent customers from going elsewhere.  She figures that in the long run this will go a long way to increase her profit margin, as one need not depend on only one line of business.

loans.use: To purchase more hair styling materials

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth O. is 45 years old and married with four children.  She lives in Ikotun, Lagos State with her husband and children.  Elizabeth sells wrappers (clothing wraps) and slippers to women in her locality.  At times she hawks her wares, taking her business from one place to another.  She needs a loan of $525 to buy more wrappers and slippers to be able to satisfy the needs of her customers.  Mrs. O. said this loan will go a long way in improving her business, thereby making it more possible for her to assist her husband in caring for their family.  She thanks you.

loans.use: Purchase of more wrappers (clothing wraps) and slippers

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en:
Deborah makes adire fabrics and supplies them to outlets. Adire is a locally made cloth, most commonly custom-patterned to suit customers’ tastes. Deborah made the cloth she is wearing in this picture, and she makes all of her relatives’ and husband’s clothes. She has been in this business for eight years and studied it for a year and a half. She said she needs a loan of $850 to buy more materials for adire making in order to meet the demand of her customers.

Deborah is the leader of a lending group. She is 47 years old and is married with a child. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more materials for making Adire cloth

loans.name: Bummi

texts.en: Bummi A. is 43 years old and married.  She and Mr. A. have four children.  Bummi sells drinks in retail to her customers.  She has been in this business for the past four years.  She needs a loan of $600 to buy directly from the company instead of buying from resellers.  She said that this will reduce costs and increase profit, which will go a long way in helping to meet her family’s needs.  She says thank you to Kiva lenders and LAPO (Kiva’s Field Partner).

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes is 61 years old and is married with 5 children.  She and her husband are both retired civil servants.  Agnes has a fish farm where she raises fish.  She supplies the fish to hotels and restaurants.  She studied this business for six months and started her own fish farm.  She needs a loan of $850 to buy more fingerling and fish feed.  She stated that this would enable her to meet the demand of her customers.  She says thank you.

loans.use: Purchase of more fingerling and fish feed

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: Mrs. Josephine O. is 39 years old, is married, and has a child.  She sells second-hand clothes, and she also sells palm oil to market women.  She has been in this business for the past seven years.  “My business is situated in a very busy location, and this has greatly improved my sales,” said Mrs. O..  She needs a loan of $700 to buy better-quality used clothes and to use in her oil business.  She says thank you to Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase better-quality used clothes

loans.name: Folake

texts.en: Mrs. Folake O. is 44 years old and is married with 4 children.  Folake sells frozen fish wholesale and retail.  Women who cannot go to the cold room to buy in bulk come to her to buy fish which they go about hawking.  Folake is standing between her two freezers where she stores fish, and on top are some cartons of fish waiting to be picked up by their owners.  Folake also sells cooked food to school children and workers who could not take breakfast before leaving home. She needs a loan of $425 to enable her to buy more fish to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more cartons of frozen fish to sell

loans.name: Aissatou

texts.fr:
Aissatou D., age 51, is married and takes care of one child. She has been a member of the village bank of Vélingara Foulbé for five years. She wants to buy some palm oil, drums, bags, and a refrigerator in order to make ice cream to sell. Her income enables her to help cover family expenses. Aissatou is requesting a loan that will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Aissatou D., 51 ans,mariée, 01 enfant en charge est membre du banc villageois de vélingara Foulbé 2 depuis cinq ans. Elle veut acheter de l'huile de palme, des bidons, des sachets et un réfrigérateur pour faire des glaces et vendre. . Ses revenus lui permettent de contribuer aux charges familiales.Aissatou sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use: Commerce in palm oil and ice cream

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria is married with a 17-year-old daughter. She has a big family, as her daughter is married and has a little son. Moreover, Victoria is taking care of two orphan nephews. She is an entrepreneur from Simferopol, where she runs her retail business in the local market called Moskoltso. Victoria owns three stores and sells cosmetics, jewelry, household items and vegetables. She has been in this business for 13 years. Presently, she has about $20,000 in inventory.   

Victoria is a dedicated entrepreneur who has a desire to achieve further expansion, conquer problems and strive for successful venture. One of her long-term plans is to open a mini-market. She is ready to take on even more responsibility to achieve her goals. Today she is requesting a loan of 5000 Grivnas ($1,100) to increase her sales and restock her inventory.

loans.use: To restock inventory and increase her sales

loans.name: Svetlana

texts.en:
Svetlana is married. She sells used clothing in the local marketplace called Moskoltso. This type of product is affordable to most Ukrainians and always sells really well. Svetlana works with European suppliers and has gained many useful skills in the past 10 years. She owns another little vending facility in the central city market, which she leases to other vendors. Currently, she has about $8,000 in inventory. Her gross income is about $5,000. 

Svetlana would like to expand her business and start selling used clothing in the central market, too. This is why she is requesting a loan of 5000 Grivnas ($1,100) to increase her stock. Svetlana is hoping to generate additional income to purchase some appliances for her house. We believe her personality traits and ability to handle pressure will guarantee further successful growth of her enterprise and prompt loan repayment.

loans.use: To increase stock

loans.name: Theresia

texts.en:
Theresia Saimon, a Tanzanian business woman for 3 years, has been selling soft drinks in the Lumo area in Dar-es-Salaam. She purchases the CocaCola and Pepsi soft drinks wholesale, and then sells the soda to her customers.

The profits from the business enable Theresia to feed her four children and pay the children's school fees. She requests a loan of $550 to purchase more soda to sell to increase her profits.

loans.use: Purchase more soft drinks to sell

loans.name: Juma

texts.en:
For 3 years, Juma C. has run a cafe in the Vituka area in Dar-es-Salaam. His customers come from the nearby small market and business people in the area.

The cafe provides enough income to feed his family and pay the school fees for his children. Juma is requesting a loan of $750 to expand his business, so he can increase his profits.

loans.use: Expand the cafe

loans.name: Mwema

texts.en:
Mwema H. is a Tanzanian business woman. She makes, purchases, and sells traditional clothes called baticki, vitenge, and kanga. She makes the batiki herself. Mwema buys vitenge and kanga in the Mnazi Mmoja city center, and sells these clothes in the vituka area outside the city center. She has had this business for two years old.

Mwema enjoys the benefits of having her own business because it helps her to feed her family and purchase medicine. She is requesting a loan of $400 to purchase more clothes to sell and increase her profit.

loans.use: Purchase more traditional clothes to sell

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Youth Self Employment Foundation (YOSEFO) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Richard

texts.en: Richard is a hard working businessman. He is 43 years old and married with two kids. He sells bananas and fresh eggs. He buys his supplies from Volta in the south eastern part of Ghana and from poultry farms around Tema. He enjoys his trade very much but the prices of his commodities and transport have gone up due to the current fuel crisis. This has rendered his capital inadequate so he can't purchase appreciable quantities to sell. He therefore needs the loan to inject additional capital into his business so he meet the demands of the market. He wants to use the loan to buy increased supplies of bananas and fresh eggs for an increased profit. Richard hopes to increase savings to pay for his kids education. He is a member of the community group called Platinum Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy increased supply of banana and fresh eggs.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sinapi Aba Trust (SAT) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en: Juliana is 34 years old and is a wife and mother of three kids. Her children are currently in school. Through hard work and support, Juliana and her husband are working very hard to support their children and give them better opportunities in life. Juliana produces batik tie dye clothes and sells them at wholesale price to other traders to sell. Batik tie dye is breech and dyed clothing designed with many local symbols. They are sown into dresses for many occasions like funerals, going to church, parties etc. She has been doing this close to three years to help support her family. As general commodities prices constantly go up, it has become difficult for her to work with her small capital. She will use the loan to inject more capital into her business to meet the demands of the market. This loan will help her increase her savings towards the welfare of her three children. She is a member of the group called Platinum. Members agree in unison to guarantee for each other to help repay the loan.

loans.use: To purchase bulk of raw materials like dye, colors, clothes etc.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sinapi Aba Trust (SAT) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Les Lingueres De Keur Mambaye Group

texts.fr:
They are part of a large group named Les Lingueres and have a lot of loan experience with IMCEC de Mbour.

They are accelerating in small-scale commerce of the district. They buy vegetables, fish, and second-hand clothing to resell in their districts, located around the community of Mbour.

These are good and honest mothers with families. They are going to use these loans to fortify their working capital.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Elles font partie d'un grand groupement dénommé les Lingueres. Elles ont une bonne expérience de crédit avec l'IMCEC de Mbour.

Elles s'activent dans le petit commerce de quartier. Elles achetent des légumes, du poissons et de la priperie pour le revendre dans leurs quartiers situés dans les environs de la commune de Mbour.

Ceux sont des braves meres de familles. Elles vont utiliser ces crédits pour renforcer leur fonds de roulement.

loans.use: To bolster working funds

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice is 36 years old and is married with five children. She is a very hard working woman and is dedicated to minimizing poverty. She is a serious business woman and works in trade. She has been successfully trading maize, beans, peanuts and charcoal for the past ten years. It is her family's primary source of income. Beatrice wants to use the loan to buy larger supply of products  to serve her customers throughout the season, especially in the face of increasing prices due to the current country's food crisis. She is a member of the trust group Platinum. Platinum members guarantee one another as social collateral and provide support for themselves to help repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy larger supply of maize, beans, peanut, eggs and charcoal.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Sinapi Aba Trust (SAT) - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Groupement  Des Femmes De Santhie

texts.fr:
They are part of a large group, Les Lingueres de SANTHIE and have a lot of experience with IMCEC (two years). They buy vegetables, fish, oil, and second-hand clothing that they resell in their districts, located on the outskirts of the community of Mbour. These are very energetic and hard-working mothers with families. They are going to invest the loan in the bolstering of their working capital, thus improving the level of the inventories and the diversity of their goods.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Elles font parti du grand groupement des Lingueres . Elles ont une bonne expérience avec l’IMCEC (deux ans). Elles achètent des légumes, du poisson, de l’huile et de la piperie qu’elles revendent dans leurs quartiers situés à la périphérie de la commune de Mbour. Ceux des mères de familles très dynamiques et travailleuses. Elle vont investir le crédit dans le renforcement de leur fonds de roulement et ainsi, améliorer le niveau de les stocks et la diversité de leurs produits. Elles habitent à Santhie , un des villages environnents de la commune de Mbour. ceux sont des femmes tres dynamiques et travailleurs. elles méritent d'etre accompagnées.

loans.use: To bolster working funds

loans.name: Alejandra

texts.en:
Alejandra weaves huipiles (the typical dress of Guatemala women) by hand and raises chickens, ducks, and turkeys. She has woven since she was a little girl, but with more simple patterns. Five years ago she began to weave really detailed and fancy huipiles, such as for weddings. These cost a lot to weave, not only in terms of thread, but also, more than anything, in terms of time. She works for up to two or three months on one huipil, but she can sell them in the city of Antigua Guatemala for 3,000 to 3,700 Guatemala Quetzals (US$400-500), depending on the quality and level of detail. Alejandra is very talented and weaves very beautiful huipiles.

She is requesting this loan to purchase more thread for weaving her huipiles and to buy more chickens and turkeys, food for them, and medicine to prevent illnesses. She also would like to make improvements to the shelter where she keeps them, such as constructing better walls and buying more corrugated tin to better protect them from the rain. Right now she has one cow in addition to a bunch of chickens, ducks, and turkeys. When they are big she takes them to the market in the nearby city of San Martin Jilotepeque for sale.

Alejandra is married and her husband works in construction in Guatemala City. They have six children ranging in age from six to twenty-one years old. All of her children have studied or are currently studying, but only up to the sixth grade because of a lack of economic resources. Her oldest son just got married in February and, while this was a very happy occasion, it cost a lot, so this loan would help Alejandra a lot right now, as resources are currently a little tight. This is her first loan with FAPE and she is really excited to have the opportunity to invest in her businesses. She notes that if she doesn’t have thread, she can’t work, so she needs this loan right away to help her continue working.

Alejandra has many dreams for her businesses and her family. She wants to expand her businesses enough to increase her income to be able to pay for more school for her children and to be able to buy more necessities for them, such as shoes and better clothing. More than anything she dreams that her children study, find jobs, prosper, and get ahead in life.

Translated from Spanish by Megan Montgomery, Kiva Fellow.

Alejandra teje güipiles (el vestido típico de mujeres en Guatemala) a mano y cría pollos, patos, y chompipes. Ha tejido desde chiquita, pero con diseños más sencillos. Hace cinco años, empezó a tejer güipiles muy detallados y elaborados, como para bodas. Estos cuestan mucho para tejer, no solo en términos de hilo sino, más que nada, en tiempo. Ella trabaja por hasta dos o tres meses en un güipil, pero los puede vender en la ciudad de Antigua Guatemala por 3.000 a 3.700 Quetzales Guatemaltecos (aproximadamente $400-500), dependiendo de la calidad y nivel de detalle. Alejandra tiene mucho talento y sus güipiles son bellísimas.

Está pidiendo este préstamo para comprar más hilo para tejer güipiles y para comprar más pollos y chompipes, comida para ellos, y medicinas para ellos para prevenir enfermedades. También tiene ganas de mejorar el refugio donde guarda los pollos, como con unas vallas mejores y más lámina para protegerlos de la lluvia. Ahora tiene un ganado además que varios pollos, patos, y chompipes. Cuando están grandes, los lleva al mercado en la ciudad cercana San Martin Jilotepeque.

Ella es casada y su esposo trabaja como albañil en la ciudad capital de Guatemala. Tienen seis hijos de edades desde seis a veintiuno años. Todos sus hijos han estudiado o están estudiando, pero solamente hasta el sexto básico por falta de recursos económicos. Su hijo más grande acaba de casarse en Febrero, y aunque este era una ocasión muy feliz, costó mucho, entonces ahora este préstamo la ayudaría muchísimo en este momento, porque tiene pocos recursos ahora. Este es su primer préstamo de FAPE, y está muy emocionada de tener la oportunidad de invertir en sus negocios. Dice que si no tiene hilo, no puede trabajar, entonces necesita el préstamo ahorita para ayudarle en seguir trabajando.

Alejandra tiene muchos sueños para sus negocios y para su familia. Quiere crecer sus negocios bastante para aumentar sus ganancias para pagar para más estudios para sus hijos y para comprar más necesidades como zapatos y ropa mejor. Ella sueña que, más que nada, sus hijos estudien, encuentren empleo, prosperen, y sigan adelante.

loans.use: To purchase thread for weaving huipiles; to buy chickens and turkeys, food for them, and medicine to prevent illnesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FAPE - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Juana Gertrudis

texts.es:
Juana Gertrudis is married and 54 years old. She studied up to the 5th year of secondary school, but did not continue studying because she got married. She has 4 children; her 35 year old son is in poor health, but the rest of her children are working.

This businesswoman began selling chicken as well as sandals from her home in the San Pedro de Lloc district of Pacasmayo province in the department of La Libertad, but stopped for a period of time because her mother was ill and she had to take care of her and had no time to work. Later on she started up again and now rents a commercial space where she sells spices and ground chilis as well as chicken.

Her daughter convinced her to participate in the "Libertad" communal bank and with her first loan of 300 soles she bought chicken and plastic sandals. With another loan for 2,500 soles, which will be repaid in 6 months, she will buy chickens and sacks of whole spices. Juana Gertrudis is currently the secretary for the communal bank and her goal is to fix up her home to make it more comfortable.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva volunteer.

La señora Juana Gertrudis está casada, tiene 54 años, estudió hasta 5to año de secundaria, no continuó estudiando porque se casó, tiene 04 hijos, su hijo de 35 años de edad está delicado de salud, los demás hijos sí trabajan.

La empresaria empezó a vender pollo y también sandalias, en su casa en el Distrito de San Pedro de Lloc en la Provincia de Pacasmayo en el Departamento de La Libertad, por una temporada dejó el negocio porque su mamá estaba enferma se dedicaba a atenderla y no tenía tiempo para trabajar; posteriormente lo retomó y se independizó, ahora alquila un local en donde vende condimentos, ají molido y también pollo.

Su hija la animó a participar en el Banco Comunal “LIBERTAD” y con el primer préstamo de S/. 300.00 que recibió compró pollo y sandalias plásticas. Con el préstamo de S/. 2,500.00 que cancelará en un plazo de 06 meses comprará pollo y condimentos enteros por sacos. Juana Gertrudis tiene el cargo de secretaria del banco comunal y tiene como meta arreglar su casa para tener más comodidad.

loans.use: Purchase chickens and spices.

location.town: San Pedro de Lloc - La Libertad

loans.name: Sonia, Marilu And Angélica Group

texts.en:
Sonia, Marilu and Angélica come from the Quinua district, located one hour from Ayacucho. Sonia is 26 and is a single mother. She has a son. She lives with her sister and takes the responsibility for her child. She sells sweets in a kiosk of the district school.

Marilu lives with her common-law husband, is 30 and has 2 children. She purchases animals in various villages, then send them to the slaughterhouse to sell them at the district food market.

As for Angélica, she is married and has 3 children. She is 31. She buys and sells cereals. With her husband, she also prepares wood that they sell in Ayacucho.

Sonia, Marilu and Angélica belong to the Los Libertadores Village Bank. They each need a 900 soles loan so as to buy biscuits, chocolates, gums, pork, hens, Guinea pigs and eucalyptus.

They dream about expanding their businesses, having their own house, and that their children will be able to study.

loans.use: to buy biscuits, chocolates, gums, pork, hens, Guinea pigs, and eucalyptus

loans.name: Isabel

texts.en:
Isabel is separated, is 57, and has 3 children. She sells chicken in a stall at the 12 de abril market, located in Ayacucho center. She has been doing this for several years.

On Saturdays and Sundays, she sells typical food in a small San Juan Bautista district marketplace. Her daughter helps her with the job. She also sells food at fair periods, for example, in the Saint Week in a popular grove.

Isabel belongs to the Morenita Huamanga Village Bank. She needs a 2000 soles loan to help her to buy a car so that her son can work as a taxi driver in the city.

She dreams about having a store at home, expanding her business, and providing her children with everything they need.

loans.use: to help her to buy a car that her son can drive as a taxi

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Rosalía Merce

texts.en:
Rosalía is separated, is 50 and has 3 children. She has a multiservice store and a fruit juice store called Mechita, in a rented place located in the 2 de Mayo street. She sells groceries, alcohol, toys, ice creams and sweets. She also prepares food she sells at the same place and offers at a boarding house. Nights, she sells french fries with sausages from a cart. Her children help her to take care of the store.

Rosalía belongs to the Morenita Huamanga Village Bank. She needs a 1000 soles loan to buy milk, juices, fizzy drinks, and yogurts.

Rosalía dreams about having a less arduous job like an Internet booth or a phone booth. She would also like to build her house and help her children to finish their studies.

loans.use: to buy milk, juices, fizzy drinks and yogurts

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Maximiliana, Hermenegilda, And Norma Group

texts.en:
Maximiliana lives with her common-law husband, is 21, and has a child. She has a little grocery store at her home with her mother and takes care of the store. She also works in a poultry farm.

Hermenegilda is married, is 62 and has 8 children. She is a mobile clothes and shoes sales person in a street next to the Ayacucho central market. On Saturdays and Sundays, she travels to fairs to sell her products.

As for Norma, she is a 26-year-old single woman. She weaves pullovers manually at the clients' requests. She also works in a wrought-iron workshop and she is responsible for the clients' reception.

Maximiliana, Hermenegilda and Norma belong to the Morenita Huamanga Village Bank. They need a 400 soles, an 800 soles and a 400 soles loan respectively to buy rice, oil, tracksuits for kids, and wool in different colours.

They dream about buying land, having a stable store, and providing education to their children so that they can be professionals.

loans.use: to buy rice, oil, tracksuits for kids, and wool in different colours

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Maribel, Valentina, And Delia Group

texts.en:
Maribel is a 22-year-old single mother with one child. She has been selling groceries in the Nazarenas market for 6 years.

Valentina is married, she is 55, and has 10 children. She sells flowers at the Magdalena market, retail and wholesale. She buys from the producers when she travels to the different communities.

Delia is a widow, she is 56, and has 5 children. She sells foods in the 12 D. Abril market in the mornings with her daughter.

Maribel, Valentina, and Delia belong to the Morenita Huamanga Village Bank. They need loans of 800 soles, 800 soles, and 600 soles respectively to buy cereals, rice, various flowers, oil, and wood.

They would like to expand their businesses, to have their own capital, and they dream that their children might be able to study in a great college.

loans.use: to buy cereals, rice, various flowers, oil, and wood

loans.name: Zaida

texts.en:
Zaida lives with her common-law husband, is 23 and has a child. She sells meat at the 12 de Abril market, located in Ayacucho center. Now she only works on Saturdays and Sundays because the other days, she studies primary education in an institute. She buys animals at fairs and then sends them to the slaughterhouse.

Zaida belongs to the Kusirikuy ("Be happy" in Quechua) Village Bank. She needs a 1400 soles loan to buy a new freezer.

She dreams about having her own house and a butcher's trade which would provide all the city with meat.

loans.use: to buy a new freezer

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Magdalena is widowed, is 46, and has 3 children. She has a little business specializing in events organization. Her services incluD. food-making, local lay-out, cooking pies, and renting a place to hold the event. She now has 4 rented places for receptions. She has employees to help her out in her various activities. She also travels to the province to organize events and family reunions.

Magdalena belongs to the Kusirikuy ("Be happy" in Quechua) Village Bank. She needs a 1600 soles loan to buy flour, butter, milk, creams, and fritters.

She dreams about expanding her business, setting up new machines, and having a car to carry her products. She also would like to have a store.

loans.use: to buy flour, butter, milk, creams, and fritters

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Miriam Elizabeth

texts.en:
Miriam is married, is 31 and has one child. Native to Huancayo, she sells supplies for silkscreen printing with her husband, such as polos prints and almanacs. She is an accredited distributor of a supplies branch. Her store is located in Garcilazo Street. She also helps her clients to use these supplies which provides her another income. Her husband takes responsibility for the graphic drawings.

Miriam belongs to the Kusirikuy ("Be Happy" in Quechua) Village Bank. She needs a 1000 soles loan to help her to buy a Sublimado machine.

She dreams about coming back to her land and implementing her business with more machines. She would also like to finish building her house.

loans.use: to help her to buy a Sublimado machine

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Julia

texts.en:
Julia is married, is 35, and has 5 children. She comes from Tambo and had to migrate from her village because of the 80s political violence.

First she washed other people's clothes. Now she sells fruit and sweets from a cart at the Señor de los Milagros school door from 7am to 7pm. Her daughters help her with the job.

Julia belongs to the Kusirikuy village bank ("Be Happy" in Quechua). Julia needs a 1000 soles loan to buy chocolates, toffees, fruit, and chewing-gum.

She dreams about having a stable business, improving her house, and she would like her children to succeed in their studies.

loans.use: to buy chocolates, toffees, fruit, and chewing-gum for re-sale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FINCA Peru - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Edith Fanny

texts.es:
Edith is a 33-year-old woman who lives with her two children. Unfortunately, her husband works far from home. She has had an apiary for 4 years. This business was the idea of her in-laws, who motivated and guided her with everything related to beekeeping. She collects almost 130 liters of pure honey. Every three months, she travels to the city of Lima in order to sell the honey. She also fills orders for her friends and neighbors. She usually attends to her mother’s shop, where she seizes the opportunity to sell honey. Her sales increase during festivities. On occasion, she even sells the honey as a street vendor in the local markets. Edith likes this job because it allows her enough time to look after her children. Her business gets into financial trouble during flower shortages in the area. Flowers are indispensable nourishment for the bees, which means she has to invest more in them during this type of situation.

She believes that her reason for working is to increase profits and her children’s well-being, since her husband’s salary is often not sufficient.

She is requesting a loan in order to obtain beehives, containers, and food for her bees. In the future, she would like to sell wholesale honey in a large store.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Edith tiene 33 años y vive con sus dos hijos, su esposo, lamentablemente y por necesidad trabaja lejos de casa. Desde hace 4 años, tiene una colmenar, se inicio por idea de sus suegros que la animaron y orientaron en todo lo referente a la crianza de abejas, reúne cerca de 130 litros de miel pura, cada tres meses viaja a la ciudad de Lima para venderla y también cubre pedidos vecinos y amistades, generalmente atiende la bodega de su madre, donde aprovecha para vender la miel, sus ventas se incrementan durante las festividades, en ocasiones, la ofrece de manera ambulante en los mercados.Edith gusta de este trabajo porque le permite tener tiempo y atender a sus hijos, su negocio se complica cuando hay escasez de flores en su zona, estas son el alimento indispensable para sus abejas, por lo que entonces, tiene que invertir más en ellas.

Ella considera que el motivo de su trabajo es para acrecentar sus ganancias en bienestar de sus hijos, ya que mucha veces el sueldo de su esposo no alcanza.

Solicita un préstamo para adquirir colmenas, envases y alimento para sus abejas, en un futuro le gustaría vender miel al por mayor, en una gran tienda.

loans.use: Purchase beehives and food for bees in order to continue honey production

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Microfinanzas PRISMA - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Elida Eva

texts.es:
Elida is 25 years old, a single mother and lives with her two small daughters.

In the past, she sold fruit juices from a street corner near her home, but she did not make any profit nor could she watch over her daughters. So she decided to open up a business at night, selling refreshments such as maca root drink, quinoa milk and bread, and with this she is able to make enough profit to support her children. She says that what she likes most about her work is that she can take care of her daughters and supervise their studies and what is most difficult is being exposed to the cold, as she sells from a small cart out in the open air.

Elida is asking for a loan so she can buy groceries wholesale and store them, and in this way not be so susceptible to increases in food prices.

Translated from Spanish by Molly Puglisi, Kiva volunteer.

Elida tiene 25 años, es madre soltera, vive con sus dos pequeñas hijas.

En el pasado, trabajaba vendiendo jugos en una esquina cercana a su casa, pero no obtenía ganancias y descuidaba la atención de sus hijas, es así, que decide abrir un negocio sólo por las noches, vende refrigerios; como agua de maca, quinua con leche, y panes, con lo que logra obtener las ganancias que le permiten sostener a sus dos hijas.Refiere que lo que más le agrada de su trabajo es poder atender a sus hijas y estar al tanto de sus estudios, considera que lo más difícil es toparse con un clima muy frió, ya que vende en una pequeña carroza en la intemperie.

Elida solicita este préstamo para adquirir abarrotes al por mayor y almacenarlos, de esa manera, no le perjudique demasiado el alza creciente de los alimentos.

loans.use: Buy food to have stored and ready for making the refreshments she sells.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Microfinanzas PRISMA - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Belinda Soledad

texts.es:
Belinda is a 31-year-old woman who lives with her husband and 5 children. She sells precooked food and chopped vegetables for a living. She started out by selling gelatin as a street vendor, but upon realizing that this business was not lucrative, she felt the need to start a business that would produce revenue for her yet not occupy all of her time. For this reason, she decided to set up a booth in the market a year ago. She opens everyday, except weekends, until noon. She really likes this schedule because it gives her time to look after her children. Her increasing clientele motivates her to continue. She has a difficult time with the rising cost of goods, which decreases her profits. However, this problem does not restrain her efforts. She is determined to improve her family’s quality of life.

Belinda is requesting this loan in order to invest it in the purchase of wholesale merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

Belinda tiene 31 años, vive junto a su esposo y sus 5 hijos.
